Nov. 13th, 1919
Endridge, Cragsmoor, New York.
My Dear Mrs. [L.W.]  Field, [Orange, Calif.]
I have just run across a couple of letters of yours to me in 1909 in one of which you speak of your little grandson having broken his arm.
I am so much interested to know if it came out all right as you were, at the time, quite worried about it.
I have put your letter, in which you speak of having had us to breakfast the morning we started down the river, in my Colorado River diary.

My son, who is now 31, was a soldier on the other side -- in France. Got to be Captain in the Signal Corps.
He is now research assistant at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, being an electrical engineer.

[2]
as it lends much interest. How well I remember that morning!
Mr. Hellers [?], Mr. Jones, Mr. Hattan, and Mr. Bishop are still "on deck", and I hope will be a long time, though Mr. Jones and Mr. Hattan are not strong. Mr. Jones has almost lost his sight -- at any rate he cannot write with his own hand anymore. He lives at Parker, S.D.
I hope you are still very well, and if I get to California again I should be pleased to call on you.
With regards
sincerely
F.S. Dellenbaugh

My dear Mrs. Field:
The clipping from the Los Angeles Examiner about the dedication of the Grand Canyon National Park on April 30th is received and I thank you very much in-
deed for your kind thoughtfulness.
I was much interested, of course, to know something about that day, not being able to get away myself to be present, but I found no mention in any New York paper of the event,

and none of my friends who were there have given me any information, so your clipping was doubly welcome a part in my files.

  I see by Mr. James's remarks that he now thinks James White passed through the Grand Canyon before Major Powell, but he is mistaken. In White's original statement he speaks of only one big rapid, whereas the Grand Canyon has a great many.
  It will probably always remain a subject for controversy but for my part I feel sure that White never saw the inside of the Grand Canyon.
  I, also, received a Parker. S.D paper with the announcement of the death of [S.] U. Jones. There

are now only three left of the original Powell parties], and these three all of the second party: Mr. Hillers who lives in Washington; Mr. Bishop - (he went with us as far as the first year carried us - to the mouth of the Paria river) - who now lives in Salt Lake and is a good Mormon; and myself.

  I hope we make the trip to the Canyon next Spring which will be first fifty years since we had that last breakfast at your house and shoved off with the waters of Green River.

With my best regards,

  Sincerely yours

F. S. Dellenebaugh

May 25th, 1920
F. S. Dellenbaugh
Cragsmoor, N. Y.
My dear Mrs. Field: above Mrs. is L.W in pencil, and to the right of the colon is Orange, Calif.

  It was most kind of you to write me and I hasten to reply to say that fortunately I am not sick, and to thank you for your inquiry.
  We failed to get off in time to reach the Canyon for the dedication of the Park, owing to some delay in a business transaction of considerable importance to me so we have postponed going for the present.
  I thought up to the last moment that I could go but it turned out otherwise. I was very sorry. However we will come along later anyhow and will take such pleasure in calling on you when we do get there.
  Hoping you are very well yourself, and with kind regards,
  Sincerely yours
  F. S. Dellenbaugh

This is my permanent address 
THE CENTURY ASSOCIATION
7 West Forty-Third Street
New York June 22d 1909
My dear Mrs. Field; L.W. inserted between Mrs. and Field and Orange, Calif is written on the side

  Your letter was a surprise and a great pleasure. I was very glad indeed to hear from you and to know that you remember our starting down the river that May morning so long ago. I could never forget that breakfast at your house - the subsequent breakfasts were in such contrast to that - and I remember I upset my coffee all over your tablecloth! The good old Major, and dear old Prof. are gone. Clem? Powell died

a few years after our return and so did the photographer Beaman. I have never heard of Andy Hattan since, but James was living two years ago in Dakota. Jack Hillers is in Washington where he has lived for many years. Mrs. Thompson is living there and so are Mrs. (Major) Powell and her daughter Mary.

  I have been married for 24 years and have a son 21 who is 6 feet 2 and weighs about 190. He is a student at Columbia University here. 
  Where is that charming daughter of yours? Mr. Field - is he dead? I always remember him with pleasure - we all liked him so very much.
  The old chair you gave

the Major he sat in all the way down the river. We had to leave it at Kanab Canyon but three years later I was in there and brought it out to Salt Lake where I gave it to Capt. Bishop. He does not know what became of it. I would give a good deal to have it now. Capt. Bishop is a Mormon now- has been for ten or fifteen years or more. He still lives in Salt Lake. I would be glad to send you with my compliments a copy of my last book. Shall I send it to this same address? Please write me some of your recollections of us at Green River.
With kind regards
Sincerely yours
F. S. Dellenbaugh

Permanent address: The Century Club 7 West 43 St New York
Mrs. Louise W. Field Orange Calif.
THE AUTHORS CLUB
SEVENTH AVE. AND 56TH STREET,
CARNEGIE BUILDING
NEW YORK
Jan. 16th 1912
My dear Mrs. Field:
Your very kind and thoughtful letter with the newspaper accounts of the journey of the Kolb brothers is just received.
I was very glad to hear from you again and exceedingly glad to know about this last trip down the river, as I have noticed nothing about it in the New York papers.
I was surprised to know that I had not replied to your last letter as I was under the impression that I had. I believe then I have not written you since Mrs. Thompson died. She died in Washington, very peacefully,

in March 1911. Mr Hillers and the Majors wife, are the only ones of the old party now left in Washington. 
How very nice for you to have your boys so near. My son is living at home this winter and goes out to Ampere N. J. every morning to his work. He is connected with the Crocker- Wheeler Co.- employed by them I should say. He is an electrical engineer and at present is designing an electric motor for automobiles.
With thanks for the clippings,
Sincerely yours
F. S. Dellenbaugh
(226 West 78th St.)
N. Y.

1
S. WHITELEY'S INSURANCE AGENCY.
POST OFFICE BUILDING TELEPHONE 168.
Racine, Wis., Dec 6 1888
DIctated   Copy
Hon. Henry C. Payne,
Miwaukee, Wis
Dear Sir: Mr. Simeon Whiteley of this city is about to make application for a consular appointment, and I submit to you some of the reasons why I must urge you to give him your most cordial assistance. Some of the facts are indeed new to me, although I have known Mr. Whiteley ever since I came to Racine.
Mr. Whiteley was one of the foremost in organising the Republican party in Illinois. He was one of the 17 Republican editors who met at Decatur Feby 22.1856, [see Nicolays Life of Lincoln] which provided for the meeting of the first Republican State Convention in Illinois. I have seen letters from Joseph Medill of the Chicago Tribune- Ex Lt. Governor Bross Ex Lt. Governor Beveridge- ex Lt Governor Shuman, editor of the Chicago Evening Journal- and Paul Selby editor of the Springfield (ILL) State Journal confirming the fact, and extolling Whiteley's abilities and character.
I believe it to be demonstrable- that the election of Lyman Trumbull to the US. Senate( and that was a turning point in the political history of this country) might not have been accomplished but for the faithfulness and almost heroic self sacrifice of Mr. Whiteley.
Mr. Whiteley has shown me a letter signed by E B Washburne. John F. Farnsworth. Owen Lovejoy, and W Pitt Kellogg. commending

2
S. WHITELEY'S INSURANCE AGENCY.
POST OFFICE BUILDING. TELEPHONE 168.
Racine, Wis.,..........188
him in the highest terms to President Lincoln in 1861- a letter which he never had occasion to use. The gentlemen named comprised the Republican delegation in the House, at that time.
The night the rebels fired on Sumpter Mr. Whiteley enlisted in the Cassius M Clay Guards for the defence of Washington City- as is shown by his certificate from the War Department
I have seen a letter from Simon Cameron, written shortly after he retired from Lincoln's Cabinet, speaking of Mr Whiteley in the warmest terms of personal friendship, and as being under lasting obligations to him.
President Lincoln in 1862 appointed him to an Indian Agency for the purpose of inducing him to go to Colorado to help bring that territory into the Union at the same time that Nebraska and Nevada were admitted. In that fight Mr. Whiteley was the Secretary of the Campaign Committee. They carried the Movement. Andrew Johnson interposed his veto- and the treacherous vote of James R. Doolittle was required and given to sustain it. Ex Governor Evans and US. Senator Teller certify to Whiteleys ability and good work while in Colorado.
In 1868, Mr. Whiteley had charge of the Presidential Campaign work in Racine on the Committee with Judge Dyer.

3
S. WHITELEY'S INSURANCE AGENCY.
POST OFFICE BUILDING. TELEPHONE 168.
Racine, Wis., ......188
In 1879 Mr. Horace Rublee came to Racine to get the late Robert H Baker to accept the chairmanship you now hold. Mr. Baker refused to accept until he had asked the advice of Mr. Whiteley and secured the promise of his assistance at Milwaukee headquarters.
In 1880 Mr. Baker insisted that Whiteley should take charge of the campaign in this County- A member of the County Committee resigned that Whiteley could be made chairman. And he won the regard of every Republican by his generalship. That was a great campaign. 
In 1884 he was again called to the leadership, but for the first time there was a factional opposition to him. Chairman Taylor came down here to see what was the matter- it having been represented to him that Whiteley had foisted himself into the position. He found Whiteley only too willing to retire- and then Taylor was at once urgent for him to remain- and he was most successful in organising Victory.
Where is the "gang" which opposed Whiteley then]
In the years 1882-4 Mr. Whiteley represented this District on the State Central Committee.
Had Mr. Whiteley's Counsel been followed, Charles G Williams would not have been defeated for Congress, in 1882

4
S. WHITELEY'S INSURANCE AGENCY.
POST OFFICE BUILDING. TELEPHONE 168.
Racine, Wis., ......188
During this year's canvass I advised Mr. Whiteley not to take any very public part on account of his official connection with our Business Men's Association of which he is Secretary: but he responded to every call- financially and otherwise- and did his full duty; contributing in many ways to our success.
Such men as Judge William P. Lyon, Judge Charles E Dyer and Mr. John T. Fish will tell you that Mr. Whiteley is a man of rare ability and deserving of any position he may ask for; and every Republican in Racine, unbiased by self interest desires his success.
Strange as it may seem this is the only position he has ever asked for on his own account. After thirty four years of constant and most valuable service, he thinks he is now entitled to it- and so do I- and I am sure that you will .In my judgement it would be a mistake to refuse him that which he desires as much as Melville Fuller desired to be Chief Justice. It is not a very big thing- but he has reasons for wanting just this position.
I can assure you that his endorsements will be beyond all question- both as to volume and character- of the very best. 
Mr. Whiteley came to Racine from England a lad in 1842- but he is in the very prime of physical and mental vigor.

5
S. WHITELEY'S INSURANCE AGENCY
POST OFFICE BUILDING. TELEPHONE 168.
Racine, Wis.,.......188
Mr. Whiteley you must remember was a newspaper man in his younger manhood; of the best of habits- extensive reading- and a man of strong convictions. He is a Republican because he could not help it- and would not if he could. and although a Temperance Man and a Methodist is as far from being a Third party prohibitionist as Senator Miller of New York.
He is not likely, if appointed, to desire to make a very prolonged stay abroad- and it will be many years before he will be placed on the political retired list among the "has beens".
But I must close- although I could add very much which would interest you.
I have thought that you would be glad to send this document to our Senators- with your earnest recommendation- but if for reasons you must decline- will you not kindly return it to me by mail.
Very truly yours.

Personal
Racine, Wis., July 10, 1881
Hon John Hay:
Dear Sir:
Nearly four years ago, your friend, Hon John G. Nicolay left his sick chamber to accompany me to the State Dept, for the purpose of introducing me to your predecessor and giving me a good sense off for the consulate at Bradford; one of many acts of kindness for which Nicolay is duly credited in my book of remembrance. "Do for Whiteley", he said, "whatever you would do for me." and Mr. Seward with all apparent warmth responded- "I certainly shall."
Later on- I formally filed an application and s??dy letters from grave Senators, jolly Representatives in Congress, ex-cellent Governors and ex-Governors, Judges of Federal and State Courts, Millionaires, Bankers, Manufacturers, Doctors of Diversity, Presidents of Colleges- and the like, all of whom you can see pronounce

me, if not the "only most-fitted" man that could be found for that- possessed of all the qualifications necessary for it, or even higher positions. After these came letters from editors of great Metropolitan Journals, and religious papers, very friendly to the Administration. 
Mr. Seward told me that it was unnecessary to get further endorsements;- that both as to quantity and quality few gentlemen came so well recommended- that there was a vacancy at Bradford- that there was no other application- that the President was very kind in recognizing his recommendations, especially for these unclear places, and he should do the best he could to secure my appointment.
Then later the President told me, in the presence of Senator Angus

Cameron and Representative Charles G Williams, that "all these English appointments were in the hands of Mr. Seward." "Remember, gentleman," he said "Not Mr. Evarts- but Mr. Seward. I very rarely interfere with the English Consulships."
I might add much more, to show upon what basis I continued in a state of expectancy and to a man with business connections of any sort. What inconvenience was occasioned thereby. I have had some experience in watching applicants for office- and noticed with almost a feeling of sadness how they would seize upon any word of the merest civility- meant to politely put them off, and accept it as a promise of the fulfillment of their wishes. I did not go to the Dept- or the President an entire novice, (although I never before appeared

in the roll of an office=seeker,) and consequently thought I knew just what value to put on the words of both.
You probably see Mr. Nicolay occasionally and he will testify how we both agreed from time to time that there has been little doubt of my going to Bradford- And Mr. Browne, your most courteous chief Clerk will tell you that I was not guilty of wearing out the carpets of your office by going early and often and staying late.-
Well, it is all right! I expect that I am quite as happy, and probably more so, than if I had been appointed. But I would give a real big apple to know just who to blame. 
You see, I have been one of those "executive" sort of Republicans, who believed that the President deserved the support of all patriotic men, and that his course made the continued ascending of the party of progress possible- in which I have had to differ

very decidedly with many personal friends, and nearly all of the federal office holders hereabouts, and I don't want to feel in all the future that President Hayes had done me a wrong, by deceiving me in a little thing like that.
Scarcely less do I like the prospect of believing that Mr. Seward sold me out, although parties were very anxious to prove to me that the reason I was not later appointed to Manchester was that the present incumbent "came down" with $600.00 which I had indignantly declined to do- or rather my friend had for me. I do not believe anything of that sort. 
Of course I am not foolish enough to think that it makes the slightest different to either President Hayes or Mr. Fred Seward- what I think of them, now or hereafter. 
There have been times where in my disappointment I could not have written

very calmly on this subject- But time has dulled the keenness of the disappointment, and I sometimes take comfort in the thought that financially at least I am better off than if I had gone. 
Still I should like to know who to remember in my prayers- as I say "as we forgive those who trespass us"
And if you cannot help me in the matter- Why I have told somebody the story- in part at least, and when you return the papers for which I herewith send a formal request addressed officially I will file a copy of this letter with them that my heirs and administration may learn how I was once foolish enough to "seek" an office and didn't get it-
Very Truly Yours
Simeon Whiteley.
[copy of notice shows
me ch n Rep Co Conn
Feb. 7, 1881-]

A.L.S. from Ralph Meeker to Whitely
Greeley, Colo. Nov.23.1879 2pp.80 in
envelope addressed to Whitely + clippings from
Chicago Tribune dated Oct 3, 1879, etc. [three?] containing
Mrs. Meekers story of the White River
Agency Massacre  by the Apaches of Arizona
The Meeker Massacre
"Susan"

Greeley, Colorado
Nov. 23, 1879
My Dear Sir,
At mother's request I acknowledge the receipt of your kind letter of sympathy and friendship of the 10th inst. Mother is so old she does not write very much, but I have no doubt she will write when she may be able.
The accounts in the NY Herald were my in views with Josephine Mother & Mrs. Price. I belong to that journal.

I understood from good authority that Susan did walk into the Council & demand the release of the captives. I have since heard that she did not. Still I have no reason to doubt my first informant for he was good authority. At any rate Susan was kind to my people & if it had not have been for her, they would have suffered [[sever?]. Is it true that she Susan was rescued from being burned where Greeley now stands?
Yours sincerely,
Ralph Meeker

friends of his who are active, an evidence of his sympathy and encourage [them]. Whatever danger there is of the election of an objectionable Senator from our State arises from the fact that so many of the Federal Officials do not treat him fairly.
I am obliged to go home to-morrow. I need not say more. If you have time and opportunity to speak with the President in regard to my application I shall be personally obliged, and I am very sure, that very many of the best friends he has in Wisconsin will be gratified if what you say should result in my official recognition.
Very Truly Yours, 
Simeon Whiteley
of Racine Wis.

Supreme Court of the United States
Washington March 23, 1877
My dear Whitely
I have been very sick for the whole of this week since I saw you -- but am much better this morning and think I will certainly be well enough to be out, and in traveling condition by Monday.
Yours
Jno [John] G. Nicolay
Simeon Whitely Esq

"Donegal," Maytown, Pa.
January 26, 1889
Dear Mr. Whitely,
I am very much gratified with your kind invitation to visit Chicago on the 90th anniversary of my birthday.
I would promise to do so at any other season, but the March winds are so raw and piercing that I am afraid it would not be safe for me to make

the venture.
I should like above all things to meet you my good old friend, and also Mr. Jones. I trust at some future time to have an opportunity to do so. How many changes have taken place since we met and what a wonderful town Chicago has grown to be.
Sincerely, your friend,
[Simon Cameron]
Mr. Simeon Whitely,
Racine, Wis.

Rochdale
                                                                                                                        Mar 21, 64.

Dear Sir,
Your letter of the 10th Feby has
reached me, conveying to me a copy
of the resolution passed by the Denver
Council of the Union League.
May I ask you to convey my
warm thanks to the Gentleman who,
"from under the shadow of the Rocky 
mountains" have expressed their
satisfaction as the course I have
taken in connexion  with unclear peat
struggle for freedom & national
integrity,  From the first I have
regarded (unclear) conflict as one
in which all living men, & all

generations of men get to live how?
a Deep interest, - for I have felt
that the failure of some free Institutions
&of yourfort? would tend to
perpetuate that is evil in the
forts of Europe, & to shout out the
hope of freedom to be achieved.
The English people will rejoice
when your war is over, with slavery
swept from the continent, & the
integrity of your great Country restored.
Our for?rning class & our
rich people have had little sympathy

with you, - but the great unclear of the
nation has been found, & wishes
to live in perpetual unity - with
their countrymen on your continent.
I thank you for your kind
letter, & heartily I thank all the
gentlemen associated with you
in the resolutions you have sent
to me.  We are far separated by
mountains & by ocean, but we
think the same thoughts for the
freedom of men.
I am with great respect

 Yours truly

John Bright
Simeon Whiteley Esq
Denver 
Colorado
U.S.A

Midhurst, Sussex
April 4 1864
Dear Sir
I have duly received
your letter enclosing copy of
Resolutions passed at a 
meeting of the Denver Council
of the Union League of
America, thanking me for
the sympathy I have expressed
for the cause of the Government
& people of the free United

States, in their struggle
against the confederacy of
rebellious slaveowners. -
It was to me a source
of painful anguish &
disappointment when I 
witnessed the resort to
physical force for the
settlement of the controversy
which has so long raged
between the advocates of
freedom on one side &
slavery on the other.
I had fondly hoped that
the new world had found

a system of government by
which the people could live in
peace, or, in case of necessity,
separate, without appealing
to the arbitrament of the
sword.  From the moment
however that the first shot
at Fort Sumptor from the
confederate cavalries, the
issue of the conflict suspended
no longer on argument, or
appeals to reason or religion,
but upon force alone; &
thenceforward my sympathies
followed your commanders

& soldiers to the fields with
all the interest in their
terrible efforts which I had
felt, in the labors of Mr
Sumner and the other
champions of freedom when
their struggle was confirmed
to the domain of peaceful
argument. -  I felt quite
confident, from the first
that however your politician
might shrink from the 
solution of the problem,
the question really  at
fore was the existence
of slavery on the whole

North American Continent.

To doubt the results would
be almost to call in 

question the exercise of a 
Divine authority over the

affairs of this world. 

Whatever else may arise

to grieve & disappoint us 

in the course of this fearful 
Civil war, we may at least

feel assured that it will 

effectually eradicate for ever

the evil from which your 

sufferings has sprung. 
And although I must

always enter my protest
against the doctrine that
the good ends of providence
cannot be attained by
peaceful means, yet if
it can be shown as the
result of this war that
four millions of human
beings have been elevated
from the condition of mere
chattels to the rank of
free men, it will be an
atonement & a consolation
for the horrors with which
it has been accompanied such

as have never yet been
afforded in the annals of
human warfare.
I beg to thank you & the
gentleman with whom you
are associated for the
kind expressions conveyed in
your letter, & unclear
yours sincerely
R??leol??
Simeon Whiteley Esq
President

(1863)
                                                                                                                                                                    Atchinson - April 2-9 pm

My Dear Wife:
I did not leave this morning on account
of some mistake about trunks; the right one
for me came this afternoon - I hope the
other fellow will get his.
You know I never worry much
about such mistakes or accidents.  If I
am not to blame myself - am so now.
I have passed the day very pleasantly
in the Printing Office a good deal of the
time, and tonight have made the acquaintance
of a man who goes out in the
morning with me - and for the sake of
whose company I would stay two days
longer if necessary.  He has crossed the
plains several times this winter - and is a 
man of that peculiar character that will
lighten the tedium of stage travel if anyone
can.  He is a great talker - but
has something to talk about, having
travelled extensively and not one of the
kind who shuts himself up in a 
state room to read a book brought from
home.  I anticipate a good time
contrary to other advisers, he goes

in for a generous lunch, and we "go in" together.
There are five passengers tomorrow - but
not so heavy a mail.
Talk about dust!  Why in crossing the
Missouri, when in the middle, I couldn't
see either shore for the dust which
blew off a bar, about a quarter of a 
mile up stream; and Mrs. Murphy saw
at tea table that she thought it a good
time to plant potatoes in the house,
there was so much dirt in the 
halls.  I think they will have one new
"Murphy" here before you have new
Carter potatoes at Racine.  The wind
has swept all the higher spots in the
streets perfectly clear - and there are large
drouth cracks all over.
There is a big trade done here
with Colorado - as well as St Jo.
I have 49 lbs to pay for at 40oc.  If I
was doing it for myself I should growl.
Freights in summer get down
to 4 & 5 cents to Denver - for our teams
which are six weeks on the way.
Good bye until I get to Denver - 6 days
and 8 days back for the letter - I love you all
the time.
Truly
Simeon Whiteley

N. SARGENT,
PROPRIETOR,
TREMONT HOUSE, FRONT STREET, HEAD OF BLAKE,
DENVER, COLORADO.
Denver, April 9. 1863
My dear Wife:
It is now 5 am. by Denver 
time. Just 144 hours since I left 
Atchison. Before shaking off the dust 
of travel, I write this to say that

I have come through without the 

slightest accident and think that 
after breakfast, I shall feel quite

as well as the morning I left Atchison.

Mon amour.
As ever
Your Affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley
Kind love to all.
Will write at length this or tomorrow evening.

Denver, Colorado.
Friday, April 17. 1863
My Dear Wife:
I was a little in hopes of getting a 
letter from you this morning, but it didn't come. 
Well, its only two days since the last one and 
so I ought not to complain. The California

Mail goes through every day, but we only 

get one tri-weekly, Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.
I am here in Denver yet, you see, 
and here expect to remain, except for a 
few days next week while I go to see about 
the property of Mr. Thomas (of Racine) who died 
at Central City- 40 miles from here, up the

Mountains, and where a Mr. Lyons of Racine
is being very successful.

To reach the Middle Park, we have 
to cross the Snowy range and some 30 
feet of snow is in the way at present.
Russell- who defrauded the Govt so 
under the Buchanan Administration

is building a toll road through to 

Salt Lake, which will be open through

this summer, and kept open during the

winter season hereafter. The Governor

thinks I can get over there in about
a month; and he is going along. 

If half what I hear about the Middle 
Park be true- it is not a whit short of

Paradise. There are the sweetest song

birds- the grandest display of flowers-

delicious water-brooks meander through 

groves carpeted with the freshest verdure.

Wheat and oats grow and ripen 

spontaneously. Ripe strawberries offer you

their lusious selves, taking special pains
to grow close to a snowbank. And if 

you should get sick- there are the waters

which will prolong your days, that you 

may live to be as old as Methusala's Great-Great 
grand parent. And it is at Grand Springs

where I am to locate. Just think of it!

A Soda Spring- a clear sparkling pure cold 
water spring- and then only two feet from
them a boiling spring discharging 100bbls 
per hour- and falling a distance of twelve

feet from an overhanging Rock.

One gentleman seriously tells me that he 
caught 300 speckled trout over there in one

day. Deer, Antelope, Bison, abound- and hunters

find grizzlies. These are the visions that are 

being held before my eyes. And then the

climate! oh such air as they have up there-
so full of life! it should be food for the Gods. 

So balmy, that I expect to see the lovely forms 
of the graces basking about in midair

in morning and evening twilight. So inspiring 

is the landscape of stream and valley, forest

and mountain top towering away above the 

clouds, that the thickest skull and the

hardest heart, yields to the loveliness and
Majesty of the Scene- and he talks nought
but poetry!.

Certainly- there is one charm to this

country, all are enthusiastic!

I think my newspaper editing isn't 
going to work. The Gov. advises me

to put all the money I can spare into
claims. Some Mills are making $2000 to $3000
per week. I will write you about the
mines by and by. Will write you
another long letter for the paper tomorrow. 

My health is first-rate. I have not

suffered five minutes inconvenience
from my old complaint since I 
left Atchison.
About 1000 people will leave here
for the Salmon River Diggins this
spring, where the gold is on the
surface; but even such people say
they believe that more gold will
be taken out here than in any
other portion of the mountains.
That it costs too much to get started
but when fairly going fortunes are 
already made.
Your picture is a heap of comfort
to me - sometimes, especially when
I think that we should be living together
again soon.  But after all,
it isn't best for me to dwell about
that - for I get in a hurry and rather
too tender.  I wish I was
made of iron.
You may read part of this to the folks at home,
also Ann & Penny Perry?
and give my warmest love to all.
Your Affectionate Husband
Simeon Whiteley

Denver
                                                                                                                    Sunday, April 19. 1865

My Dear Wife:  It is a little too bad that
I have to leave in the morning before the
coach comes in which will certainly
bring me a letter.  However, as I expect
to be able to get it next day, it won't
be quite so bad.  I think it very 
likely that I may stay about the
mines all the week.  I don't know
yet.  I shall take my pen along and
perhaps will get a chance to write you
a line from that elevated position.
Some four or six days before you
receive this, you will hear of a terrible 
fire which swept tolerably clean the
business part of this city.  It is said that
extravagant estimates of the loss has been
telegraphed east.  The best estimates have put
the loss at $234.000.00.  To individuals, the
loss will be very severe, but it will
result in a very great improvement to
Denver.  The pine of which they build
here is full of pitch, and with the

extremely dry state of the atmosphere;
it burns as readily as so many paper
houses would burn.  Every hardware establishment
(but one) was destroyed.  A great
many "Greenbacks" were also burned.
Of course little else is talked about,
or drank about.  Of course, a fire is always
the excuse for getting drunk - and there are
a great many fellows about town in
that state.  I did not see the fire itself;
but the light woke me up - and
I heard the landlord tell his wife that
it didn't amount to much - and so
dropped to sleep again.  Mrs. Sergeant
has been insane, and her husband
didn't want her to get excited.
The fire came within a stone throw
of our hotel - the Fremont.
As I came home from church this
morning.  I saw loads of building materials
being handed to the burnt district.  Some
men are quite excited, but there is not
anything that looks like discouragement 
or even gloom.  Fortunately - the fire occurred
at a time when stocks were

low, and can very easily be replenished.  Had
it occurred in the fall, the loss would
have been much greater, and perhaps
much suffering would have resulted
from the loss of provisions.
I did not go to church until 11.20 expecting
to be too late; but there were only
five or six there.  In 20 minutes more
there was about 100 and then services began.
It was about as bad last Sunday.
I intend going to the Episcopal Church this evening.
We have a very fine melodeon which Mrs. Hillard plays.
Gov. Evans is going to build him a house.
Building materials are not so high as I expected.
Lumber is quoted at $1700 per 1000ft or was
yesterday - and brick laid in the wall at
$10 to $11.  But carpenters get $5 00 per day.
I played a game of eucher the other evening
in an office which Mr. Traver built.  Several
people has asked me if I knew him, and
said they would be glad to see him in
this country again.
The regulations require that I stay
within the bounds of my agency, except

when on leave of absence; but there
is going to be little or nothing for
me to do up there so far as the
Indians are concerned.  People still
say that it will be a month before
I can get over the range.  The Gov.
thinks I shall be able (legitimately of course)
to make some money over there, without investing
a dollar.  I think it is so.  Ranch men 
have already gone over the
range on snow shoes to begin
farming operations - so I heard yesterday,
and people say that by the
time I get into the valley, that
grass will be waist high.
Did I tell you, that in my first walks,
I found a little yellow violet in the dry bed
of the Cherry Creek.  Well this morning I found
what had been a silver teaspoon.
Father may tell Miller that I could not
find any boot/shoe dealer here of the name he
gave me - and think he must be in the
mountains.  Such boots as he was making
would not sell for more than $8.00 in Denver.

There are a great many Wisconsin
people - men - here I think more than from
any other State.  The ladies generally at our church
dress rather more stylish than at Rochester - far
more costly than our Methodists at Racine:
but they are mixed.  Mrs. Evans and Willard
don't go in on colors much.
Mrs E. wears pretty nice diamond rings.
There is not the flash of California
here by any means, but money seems to
come and go right easy nevertheless.
Farmers are making a great deal of
money.  A man with 50 cows - has just
let them for 6 months at $60.00 per head, and
all calves to be returned with cows.
Freights to Atchison and Omaha - are down
to five cents per lb.  Homes are cheaper
here than at Racine.  People keeping house
here can live pretty cheaply.  but
choice cuts, is about 15c per lb.  Potatoes, not
the nicest perhaps, but fair potatoes - large and
sound 50 to 75 per bushel.  Potatoes they grow
large over here - and plenty in a hill.

I shall have to postpone my newspaper
letter for a day or two.
It now seems that I am going to have
a good deal of time to write, but I 
cannot of course write the same thing
to everybody about the country - and
I shall be glad if you get the slips printed.
I have not written to anybody
yet except Dr. Hanen? & Doug?
and shall not perhaps for some days,
other than business letters.
Such a day as this is no wonder
the people boast of the climate.  But
the lack of trees makes the town
look awful lonesome sometimes.
Now haven't I written you lots
since I came here?  And don't I 
feel good over being so well?
Give my kindest love to all
and tell them to write often.  There
are somethings in this letter perhaps
not worthwhile to read to all.
The ink you use is a little too red,
but looks very well.  I haven't any
of Havens to compare with it.  Do you

Baker of Racine is about 4 miles away.
Mrs. Davidsons brother about 2 miles.
I mail a letter to Rounds today, that
I do not propose to buy his share in the
news.  It pays big, but I am not wanted in 
the concern, by anybody, at present.
Gov. Evans stands A no 1.  He is managing
his cards very well.  He expects that
Congress will pass the Enabling Act in 
December next, if Mr. Lincoln has his 
own way about it.  And before many months
thereafter perhaps Evans will be a U.S.S.
He still insists that Mr. Doolittle owes him
an explanation regarding his pledges
to him last spring concerning my
appointment.   I have the most satisfactory
reasons for believing - I now
know that Evans was very anxious
to have me come here, and he is
exceedingly glad that I did come finally.
Nothing could be more natural
than that he should want me - of nearly
all others to come.
He, at any rate was not lukewarm.

shake the bottle well.  The ink I am 
writing with is made from those
ink powders.
I am sorry about Bill's picture
and hope you bought her a new
Album.  I wonder if she is really
going to Aurora this summer.
You visited at Whiteheads of course
somewhat.  The more severe you
are on those who call old Abe
a fool the better.  I just stop
talking when that begins. Cole?
won't get a good picture if she
sits so that the light, however
dim shines in her face.
Goodbye darling.
Your Affectionate Husband
If you haven't sent for the Independent yet - hold on.
I will try to earn that money and more.
Simon Whiteley

Denver April 27. 1863

My Dear Wife:
I have received from you five
letters since I came here dated the 1st, 5th, 10th, 12th and 16th April.
That of the 12th came while I was in the mountains, that of the
16th a few minutes ago.  How eagerly
I watch for them, nobody else knows.
You see this being Indian Agent
is a queer position.  Last week I was
more than halfway to the proposed post,
but the rest of the way is blocked up.  I can
see the very drifts from my window 60
miles away, - or could a few minutes ago,
for as I turn my eyes from this sheet
thitherward, I find the snow range hid
by a wild snowstorm which intervenes
while I am in my shirtsleeves, enjoying
the most agreeable temperature in a 
agi?able, neither warm nor cold.
I told the Governor this morning that
I was just beginning to appreciate
the compliment involved in this appointment.
No "short sighted" individual

for Denver is a dull place indeed for an idle man.
My visit to the mountains was very full of interest,
and in my letter to George Jackson you
will get a pretty full account of it - as I shall send the letter
first to you.  Mr. Lyon of Racine is very
rich already - his prospects are perfectly dazzling.
His partner Towne is brother to the Town
who was Vice President of the Kane Co. Ag So.
when I was Secy; a particular friend of
mine, whom I have known well for 14 years.
Turning from their office who should I see
coming up to greet me but Flack the ex Conductor -
(who passed our wedding party free) and Jim Clark,
for many years Master Mechanic in the R.R shops at Aurora.
Then I found Frank Parmalee the Chicago Omnibus
man- so I was right at home.  Flack seemed
as if he could eat me up (he was so tickled)
he took me everywhere, showed me everything and all about it -
told me about everybody past, present and future, especially future.
More people know me at Nevada, Central City, Eureka, and Black

would answer at all.  It requires somebody
who can "see beyond his nose," even though
he had a longer proboscis than myself.
Who would have thought a few years
since, that I should be employed by
the Government at $1.500 per anm, to 
sit here in Denver with my face Westward,
and just at a sharper angle - just 
to watch the state of the snow which
caps the grand Corderillas!  What agreeable occupation!
Who would not exchange the
dull routine of Bureau life at Washington
for such elegant repose as this?
And as there is more snow on the range than
when I came here, 18 days ago, the prospect is
that I shall not be disturbed.
There!  Oh, Jane, if you could but just
see that sunburst upon Longs Peak (the very
Peak - for the base half is still enveloped in 
the storm) - you would say indeed that you
were well paid for the long and tedious stage
ride across the plains.
The mountains grow upon my right - the
longer I look, the more majestic they seem,
and no wonder I look at them,

Hawk Point than in Racine County. I remember
many of their names, but when I go back I shall
have them wonderfully jumbled.
If anybody's cow ever run with anybody else's cow, 
anybody and anybody else are old friends in this
country- until they quarrel, and as I have found
lots of people who had acquaintances in Racine,
and Chicago and Aurora, that I know, you 
see everybody is my friend. Esq Rockwell of
Beloit sends his kind regards to Father.
When I had mailed the little note to you
on Friday last, I discovered the little white flower
in my pocketbook. I picked it away up on the 
summit of the mountain at the base of which Central
City is built. I was not there half an hour, but
in that time two inches of snow had evaporated
under the warm sun and the very vapor turned to 
snow again and whitened the ground again.
I enclose you the flower this time, as well
as a blue one which I picked at the base
of the mountain- at Golden City- where Geo. Misner's?
brother "Doode" and his nice family resided 
for two years past. They live 18 miles North
of there now, at St. Vrains.
More tomorrow for the paper-
Affectionately- Simeon Whiteley

Denver. Apr. 24 1863.
My Dear Wife:
I have just come down
from the Mountains of which I have
no time to write you now, except that
I am so delighted that you would
think I had found a gold mine.
Whether you ever come here to 
live or not, you will have 
to come to see these hills- for
no one is fully prepared to leave
this world until they have seen
its sublimities.
I enclose you a little
flower which I picked out of the snow on the
top of one of the lower ranges-
but still some 20,000 feet nearer
heaven than you are.
I can only write this much
as it is mail time, and no more
for two days
As ever. Simeon Whiteley

Denver, May 4, 1863
10
My Dear Wife:
I have intended to ask several
times but forgot before the close of my
letter what the Chicago artists said
about the photographs of our Mothers.
and also to inform you that Mr. Allen
who was to have married us, is said
to be living on a farm (ranch) about
five miles from here.
I have just come in
having got my letter from you, and 
carried a couple to Mrs. Evans- 
the Doctor having gone up to his
claim. He and Elbert have just bought
a 2/3 interest in a claim from which
two cords of ore per day are being raised,
and some of it yields $1,000 per cord.
The cost of raising and crushing is about 
$110 per cord. What price they have
paid I don not know, but he assures
me that with the additional machinery

he is going to put in,

that the claim will pay all the

purchase money as fast as it is due
after the first payment.
Mrs.Evans is very contented here, 
and she says she expects you along
very soon whether I send for you
or not. I think I told you that
the Gov. was going to build a nice
brick house here this summer. She 
dresses very plainly, and in mourning
for her little five year old daughter
which died just before she left Evanston.

I don't see her or little Millie? or Willie?

much; but unclear likes to be about with
me.
Doctor Dyer? gave me a very hearty letter
of introduction to a nephew of his here.
He is going to have his family here
in about three weeks. They are now
below Pikes Peak near the New Mexican
line. I am in hopes that will furnish
me a good place to live while I am 
in Denver.
Yesterday after dinner, he brought up a
pony for me to ride- so I went down
to the Barracks to see Mrs. Doctor Vance,

who had sent her husband to see if I was the 
S.unclear of Aurora. She is a niece of Isaac Gilson
of Aurora; perhaps you will recollect her as
a young girl who had burnt her right hand
or rather her fingers off. She appears
to be a very nice woman, tho' she is
living in camp, and she was very glad
to see me. Her husband is a son of
Ex Gov. Vance of Ohio, used to drink a
great deal, but has reformed. She was
very glad to get the news I could give
her from Aurora.
I thought I had a very pleasant
ride of four miles, but this morning
I found myself quite stiff about my
shoulders. In Kansas as well
as here, Indian ponies are very
plentiful and are worth from 
about forty to seventy dollars.
Here in Denver, the season does
not appear to be very far advanced.
The few Cottonwood trees are mostly
leaved out and look quite green, but
there is nothing else except the
grass, and that you can hardly tell

anything about. In some places it is
quite long, but then it doesnt make
the ground look green, far away from
the river bottoms it grows in mouthsfull here

and there sand, and cacti filling 

the intervening space.
At the foot of the Mountains, 15 miles
away, there is a good deal of vegetation
and I should think that there
everything was a month or six weeks
ahead of Racine. We have spinach
grown out of doors, and pie plant two
weeks since, two feet long. But it is
the general absence of anything to indicate
the change of seasons which makes
me feel strange. I sat out on the
porch the other evening until ten
o clock without feeling cold- and 
yet in the middle of the day I
have felt no inconvenience from
the heavy clothing I bought- wearing
flannel drawers and the woolen shirts
you made. When I came, I spoke
of the delightful temperature of the 
atmosphere. "We have had it just like this
nearly three months" everybody said.

And yet I see it snow up in the
Mountains every single day, more or
less.
The sunset scene last night was
most lovely. You recollect that one
when we were at the mouth of
the river where the little steamboat
took a load off the Lady Elgin, where 
Josephine took a fish on my hook.
Well that was splendid; so was
the one last night. There is one
glory of the sun- another of the
moon, another of the stars- but
one star different from another
star in glory. That Lake Superior 
sunset was as the faintest
glimmering star glory compared to the
sunset of last night. Such colors
I never saw before in earth or 
heaven; and one combination there
was to which the nearest approach
is the color of the ink you use-
only behind it seemed to be a white
light. But pen, nor brush could

Wm H Russell of whom I shall
probably have to write more
He says I shall have to stay 
on this side until the 10th of
June! I felt pretty blue that
day. I guess you had better
write about three times a week
for a while- I want a letter
every mail.
I have had not a line from
any one else but you, darling,
since I have been here.
Yours come in just eleven
days.
Good night, darling.
Simeon Whiteley

do the subject justice even tho
unclear used the one and Lustre the
other.
But with health apparently
reestablished, all trouble removed
from my mind, and freedom
to wander about and enjoy all 
this feelings are awakened
which defy my pen to reveal,
or my tongue to express- unless
you can full interpret all the
meaning of the words which
come unbidden. 'O that Jane 
was here to see this".
Certain it is that this is a 
great country to visit; and 
perhaps the time may come when
with improved Society, it will be
a good country to live in. It
is said to be improving fast.
What must it have been?
It is mail time and I must 
close briefly:
I have made the acquaintance

Denver, May 4, 1863. 8 1/2 P.M.
My Dear Wife:
The letter which I have just
taken to the post office was cut short, and
so here you shall have the conclusion.
I expect it will surprise you to learn
that I have nearly six weeks to remain
here doing nothing. It made me feel
pretty blue. I had before began to get
impatient, and had made a partial 
arrangement to go over with Mr. Bangs, a half
brother of Wm H. Russell, on foot, just for
the novelty of the thing, but my friends
advised me so earnestly to give it up- 
on account of the hardship, that I did
so. Other parties have been at me 
today to fix a time to go with pack mules,
but a letter from Bangs says that even
is impracticable, and as the Gov. wants
to go when I make my first official
visit, we must needs wait for wheeling.
Mr. Russell was a great friend of
Floyd and Drinkard. Mrs. D. used to speak
of him kindly, very. Father will know of him.

Well Russell is building road over
the Range- and the steepest grade is
not to be more than 575 feet per
mile. This will reduce the
distance to Salt Lake nearly two hundred
Miles (from the Mo. River.) 24 miles of
road is to cost $125,000. The road is to 
go by the Boiling Sulphur Springs
where "Grand City" is laid out. All
that country belongs to my Indians.
Such is the attraction there that
several large parties of ladies
and gentlemen went there last
summer on pleasure excursions,
over such roads. On the 4th of July
next it is expected that a thousand
people will celebrate the day there,
and honor the completion of Russell's road.
Russell got Gov. Evans to fix the day.
and a good joke it was for Russell is at
best-a- Peace Democrat. Of course the
Gov. will be there with his family.
About 100 claims have been staked out
in the Park this spring. It is in the
park where "Moss Agates" (most beautiful,
(stones) are found; and where it is thought

that some of the richest gold lead and gulches
exist. Dont you want 160 acres over there - and
other interests? Is it best to locate the
Agency and Military post at Grand City?
Remember I have nothing to say about
it officially. Grand City is only
the same distance from Central, (at present
the richest mining region here) that
Denver is. It is too high up to raise Corn,
but for everything else, is a vastly
superior agricultural region to that on
this side the Mountains requiring no irrigation. Remember this
is what everybody says. Well, as rich an
agricultural region as is described- ten to
fifteen miles wide- thirty long- with
several arms, might support a larger
population of miners. The utter
inexhaustibility of the gold mines, not a
single man that I have talked with
doubts for a moment. Agriculture will
pay. Of course the railroad to the Pacific
Ocean is to go through Denver and Grand
City. Not up that high grade-O. no-
but through the mountains- and the 
gold ore taken out of the tunnels

is to pay the expense of tunnelling.
All that we are waiting for, to realize
these "air castles" is for the war
to close- the army and the contra
bands to be liberated. They will be
attracted to this kind of labor after their
long years of idling about the camps
as bees to honey!
There is some sense in the way
Russell talks. He isn't much taller
than I am- but he has got a big
head on him; and he is not proof
against the inspiration of the grand
scenery, and gets enthusiastic. He is
always doing big things- and he is very
popular here with the people, or
would be but for his Southern proclivities.
I expect to spend some days at
his place- "Idahoe" in a fortnight,
among the mines, gulch and leads.
[How I wish the piano down stairs
was in time, and the lady's voice wasn't
cracked. She tries hard to sing the good
old songs of Home, but unfortunately
she never learned how to sing well.]

Every coach from the east comes
loaded. Mr. Rockwell of Beloit brought
his family last week. A gentleman who
last year was at work for an Irish
man names Pat Casey (at $800 per anu.) come
down and met his wife and three daughters, 
a most lovely appearing family, ladies
everyone of them of culture and good
breeding. I never saw a man's cup of
happiness seem to be running over so
fast. How proud he was of them. He
hadn't seen them for three years, and
a year since hardly dared to hope
he should for three more; but his
employer dispensed with his services,
he went to work on his own claim,
and had been taking out $1000 per
week clear of all expense for the
last four months. In four or
five more years he would have
all the money he would ever
want and they would have
all the money they would all
need, and then they could go
back East if they wanted.

such a fool as to come out into this
country and because I made a thousand
dollars in a day, should begin to delve
in that spot for more, and continue
day and night, all day until the stars
came, all night until they faded away,
-month in and month out- blasting
the rock which gave way sometimes
eight inches in twenty- four hours,
until I was so poor that I couldnt
get trusted for a place to lean against,
until my partners and men all left me- and every
body laughed at me as I went by
and said "There goes that poor fool Flack."
and I knew I was a fool as well as they
did, until one day I got through the
Cap. 173 feet of "cap"- and there lay the
precious "iron." And then Presto! Change!
First came my partner- oh yest!! and
it was "how do you do my dear fellow- God
bless you- lets take a drink- and
can't we sell you something to-day-
&c &c. The fellows good luck has been
too recent, for him to have shed his 
buckskin pants which he has worn

" Mr. Whiteley", he said " I have given them
all a fine education if nothing else"
he would say; And as they played
on the piano and sang, he would
add- " well they have a better piano
than that on the road- be here in
a week."
I couldn't help thinking that it was
too bad that the man never would
be so happy again in all his life.
I hope the piano will have arrived
when I next go to "Central". 
Among other parties who have come
out in the Coach, are sundry Old heads
from New York, Philadelphia and Boston,
- said to be heavy capitalists. There
must be more of them next year.
It takes money to make money here,
or else such agony as poor Flack
has gone through with. "A thousand
times" says he. I have gone out in the 
night, laid down on the ground and 
bellowed like a calf- wondered what 
peculiar quality there must have
been in my mothers milk to make me

Sunday and all for two years and
a half.  He doesn't look like the
"bandbox conductor" much.
Three companies failed in sinking
the shaft of the Bobtail lead.  Mr. Field (for whom that Mr Thomas of Racine worked)
bought it for a son.  In 
two days he struck the iron
pyrites which yielded over $1500 00
to the cord, and he has - it is said
"retorted" $100.000 in four months.
only leaving 33 feet - or one third
of a claim.
But of these things bye and by,
when you will certainly think
I am either very credulous, or have
got "iron pyrites on the brain" perhaps.
We are expecting the Indians
who have gone to Washington
to return soon.  The Gov. then
intends to go down to the Arkansas River.
I hope to be invited.
Have written to some eastern papers
for an engagement to

write for them, but it will be
two weeks before I get any answers probably.
I am going to have plenty of time to write occasionally
at least; and I am in
hopes to be able to determine something
about my prospects for
bringing you out, when we go
to the Park.
I wrote to Joseph W? to day.  A
line to Perry last Saturday, but
to none other of our folks yet.
You must be sure to send the
papers, and get me slips or
copies - of each, as occasionally
I may want to use some.
Have just got the May Atlantic.
If I gave my "Gold Foil" away,
I forget - please buy and mail me another;
and please also do tell father
to let you know whenever
he wants any money to pay
those matters of mine.  If you
have it, let him have the amount

and I will send you whenever
you call for it, for that purpose.
I never was so careful of my
expenditures before in my life, since
I was an apprentice at $35 00 per ann.
Tell Joseph Jackson when you see
him that I reciprocate his compliment.
Let us reverse the order of the names
and he spoke my mind exactly,
but tell him that I don't find the
place yet where a kip boat made
in Racine would sell for $1500  I 
hope that Miller of Racine gets his
money all right.
But I will bid you good night
and pleasant dreams.  Tell father I am
almost glad that the Republican party
was beaten in Chicago.  This is no time
for parties.  It was a little too bad tho
to beat so good a man as J.B Bryan
by Frank Sherman.  But the Jo. Medill
demagogism wouldn't work.
Good night Simmy

Denver, May 6 1863

My Dear Wife:  I got yours of the 26th
to day and it made me feel wonderful well.
I got by the same mail, the Advocate,
two Beacons, and The Sunday Morning Chronicle.
I can imagine just what beautiful
Spring weather you are having, and how
you enjoy it after a Northeaster, and I believe
I should enjoy that the best myself in the
long run.  Now we haven't had an 
unpleasant day since I have been here,
except once or twice when it was a 
little heavy, and the dust blew about
some, and don't you believe that
human nature is such that one
really gets tired of it.  There isn't a 
garden in this whole town that I have
seen yet - I mean a flower garden
with shrubbery.  A good many attempts
to plant Larches, Firs and Pines have
been made and failed, for want of
constant irrigation I suppose.  
The time will come however when our
abundant supply of water will be

you.  Aside from my relatives I don't
know of anybody else that I care
to have you send to - except 3 or 4 to me.
There is in Phoebes request for
a copy of Larrabes picture, something
painfully sad.  It is so long since he died.
I guess I wouldn't say anything about it ever, so that
it would get back to Aurora.
Let her have it by all means - and 
if she sends any money for it
return it with the picture.
Poor Phoebe!  She has fallen a victim
to false notions of Propriety  and
repelling every expression of natural emotion.
But this request shows
that there is a very deep undercurrent
of feeling.  I guess she has suffered
a good deal too: or else she would
not have been teaching that school.
When you write to her again - of
course you must give my kindest
regards to her - and to the Bradys's &c
I wrote to L.D about that Masonic

bought here, and then the desert
will blossom like the rose.  Two
more men went East this morning
on the coach for their families.
Women will bring taste.  Refinement, and
Christianity with them,
when they come as wives, mothers
and sisters.  No stronger proof
is needed that it is not good
for man to be alone, than the state of society here.
My friend Homans who painted
up life in Denver so highly, had not lived
in Racine or Aurora.
I presume it is about as good
here as in Omaha.
You can address Judge Jones as 
"Hon John Penn Jones" Washington D.C" This
paper I received today is an acknowledgement
of a letter I wrote him three weeks ago, and in which I enclosed
some flowers, like I sent you.
I wrote to Gov. Bangs, that you would
furnish him slips if he desired
them, and presume he will write

document just before it came.
For two days past I have been
running the Governors office alone,
while he, Sec'y Elbert and the office 
clerk are all up in the mountains
in testimony whereof I leave hereto
affixed the Great Seal of the Territory.
This 4th day of May in the year of our Lord 1863.
By the way the Miners Register at Central
notices the arrival of Gov. Evans
and Lady at the "Metropolitan."  Mrs. Evans is here.
There is very little war excitement here.
There are but few Secesh - but
those who are are Southerners.
A great many Georgians came to this
country and some of them are here
yet.  There was a little stir yesterday
for a few minutes on the appearance
of the news that Hooker had
got in the rear of Fredericksburg, but
it all settled down again to the
old story of how much "Retort" this
or the other Lode had yielded in 
a week.  Goodbye - I love you.
Simmy

Denver May 11 1863

My Dear Wife:
Yours of April 29 arrived this morning and it did me a power of good.
I am glad that you enjoyed the letter which I didn't write to the paper.
I expect it was a little better than the others, for
somehow, I have been out of the newspaper business so long that I can't
write anything which I know is to be
printed without trying - and trying ruins it.
Gov Bangs can write a very friendly letter:-
there is something about him very attractive when one gets acquainted
with him.  God intended him for a very superior man, and if he only
had faith enough to believe that honesty was the best policy - that
truth would always pay in the long run - he would not frustrate
the original plan.
I got a letter from Perry the same date as yours which I may have an

I am very cautious you know; and I don't
want father to come if thereby he would
have to resign his assessor ship.  Perhaps
Mr. Cram could leave without any great sacrifice.
They may neither of them have any money to put in.
I don't know, but that they would "make" by the trip I have no earthy
doubt; the time to come is now - the
tide is only beginning to set in.  New discoveries
are being made everyday- but there are plenty of well - established lodes
which men are too poor to hold - or to work; already in debt, paying
interest at not less than ten per cent
per month - struggling like drowning men,
they must sell.
I shall not write the letter I intended
for Gen. Jackson at present, but will send
him a little note instead.  I shall take
plenty notes up in the mountains this time.
Don't know when I shall return to Denver.
The Gov. got a letter from a military post
up by St Vrains, last night, saying

opportunity of answering tomorrow.
On Wednesday I go again to the mountains.
I want to get posted by the time father or Mr Cram
come out.  I shall go this time to Empire which is only about
ten miles from the summit of the range.  I am going to take with
me $120 00 worth of In. Rev. stamps to put on
the little deed to the Gold Dirt Lode
which Gov. Evans, Secy Elbert and another
party have purchased.  A Boston company
made a purchase a fortnight since which required two deeds,
and the stamps required amounted to $1.180.00.
I don't want to scare anybody away
by making them think that the
excitement is up and that big prices
are being paid.  This does not appear
to be the case, and I don't think that
they will reach very high this summer because
as yet buyers are so few.  The chances look better
every day.  If father doesn't, I hope
Mr. Cram will come out very soon.

that the Arrapahoes were about to 
put to death a late squaw which
they had captured.  The soldiers rescued
her and so I shall have a nice 
present to take to "my People" when
I go.  I wish I was a "Brave" instead.
A little tobacco would compensate
for a squaw - it would take a pony
to balance a "Brave."  But I shall
be a good friend if I take them
a squaw.  Don't be jealous, if she
is no cleaner than the Sioux I saw
on the way.  There is a surgeon here
who has been vaccinating the Indians, along the Platte - he
says he only found one of the "Braves" clean enough to operate
upon without first washing the spot.
I told you before that I wrote to
LD Brady about my Dermit?  I received
a very warm letter from him last
week.  He hopes that you will visit
them this summer and that we
shall both together on my next visit home.

On Saturday afternoon, I paid
Mr and Mrs. Millard a visit.  They
had just come down from the mountains
with the Gov.  The first thing was the production of the two boxes
of "Specimens" - some of them beautiful.
They please me much better than
"shells" I like them both very much.
He is an excellent preacher.  She
invited me to tea; but I declined.
Then sometime next week - she said.
Alas I shall not have time before I go.
I had another invitation today to the Surveyor Generals house
to play "Whist," but am engaged this evening at The League - if you
must know - which I started here on Saturday Evening.
I expect Jonthan? ?isner over
here after me this week - but
I shall be gone.
How glad I was to get the letter from Rod.  If you will
write a few lines to Belle - I will

what she says commencing with the
paragraph on page 8th - "Life turns out so differently."
I don't know her creed, but I like her "Experience."
It is just that which she is telling, and
I think (whether she belongs to the Church or not) that she knows something more
of the heights and depths of the love of God than a good share of the poor
travellers Zionward.  But read the
whole article, at first a little too wordy perhaps, but take time and
have plenty of patience.
We had the first rain since I came (in Denver) last night - and today
the mountains are shut out from view.  
It looks as if they had been removed, for it seems as
if we could see twice as far to the west as where, they seemed to be
yesterday morning.
I saw a funeral this afternoon.  They had a hearse; but there
was no woman in attendance and it looked sad.

mail it with mine, bye and by.
I sent note a Sandwich Island paper 
the other day and to Mrs. Fawcett in
England - another, also one from Virginia city - Denver City and Santa Fe'.
I should say go to Green Bay and
go to Aurora, but I don't want to spend another dollar unnecessarily.
Mind, I don't call a good book unnecessary - nor attendance upon
the Tableaux over Readings which
you recently had.  I know they
were good - calculated to do you good - and I really hope you went.
I have received the back No's from Jany to the Atlantic.  
I enjoyed the "Happiest Days" article by Gail Hamilton largely;
better on the second reading than the 1st.
Perhaps she has had an experience
somewhat like mine - and that
is why I like the article so well.
How often I have told you in
my poor way the substance of

My health continues excellent.
I have asked myself if the exuberance of my spirits and
my sanguine temperament had
anything to do with the offer
I made to Father and Mr. Cram.  Perhaps so, but
then perhaps no more so than if I had leave to take
almost the first pick from an orchard of splendid peaches
which somebody had raised with care - and said - "Go help
yourself and get your friends to help you, only don't touch
certain trees.
But I can't see - it is dark.
Remember I love you
As ever
Simeon Whiteley

Denver, May 24, 1863
                                                                                                                                               10.45 pm

My Dear Wife:
When I came down from the mountains last Wednesday.  I thought
that I certainly should write you a very long letter next day, but it took me
so long to get caught up in sleep that with some other little trifles, that day passed.
Then Thursday I had to wait for the coach to come in and bring me another
letter from you:  which it didn't, and then I delayed until after tea.
When I met my old friend Frisner; and of course 
I had to go and see his wife and then
I didn't get my letter in season, and so I tore it up.
This having so much to tell is a bad thing sometimes, it's a big job to sit down
and write it all.  Well I shan't undertake it tonight.  But I will tell you
how I have passed to-day - which is Sunday:
After breakfast I went to the Stage Office and waited an hour for
the Eastern Coach, so as to see the Mess-

Singing is really good - Bro Millard makes us
good prayers as any Unitarian - and I very 
much enjoy going to church - only that
when I know that I am half an hour
behind appointed time it makes me ache
to wait another 20 minutes for congregation and services.
We had a splendid supper too, but I ate
very light, so as to be in good shape for
writing; but the sun came down so hot that I was drowsy, and so took
a nap.  After that Mr. Towne from 
the mountains came in to sit a while
and Mr. Bliss followed.  Bliss has quit drinking altogether.
After  tea, I stood by the door and a bright little girl five years old
said to me - "if you will come here I will tell you something."
She is the daughter of a Mr (S.G I think) Fields late of Beloit,
has just come on this week (Mr Fields says he knows father very well.)
Of course I went, and she imparted to me in strictest confidence
that the mother of the little tiny pretty bit of 
sweet baby in the parlor there was

messenger, to learn if he had heard anything of Major Cauley who is on his way from Washington with a couple
of the Chiefs.  "Nix" - "Nihil" - to "mix dialects."  So we conclude he has taken
the Southern route and is down on the Arkansas River.  Thence to the
"News" Office to read the dispatches from Julesburg - one days drive - but the
dispatches were three days old.  Thence
to fix up for Church; this is the first time I have not put on a 
white shirt to attend church.
(I do feel so funny in one; - as I put it on,
I fancy myself an Episcopal Bishop.)
Brother Millard preached a splendid sermon
on Practical Religion.  Have I told you about our Church?
It is about 45 x 20 feet; two rows of seats; aisle in the centre.
Ladies to the right.  Mrs. Millard plays the Melodeon
and does good plain singing - aided by a few friends;
the Congregation join tolerably well; your husband makes a loud noise,
especially on the 1st verse - invariably forgets
to put a troche in his pocket.

going to have the baby's picture taken some day when they went back to Wisconsin,
and then she (the little girl) was going to have one of them.
So then of course she came up stairs with me, and I showed her Delia's picture and
she chattered away for a few minutes, ran down stairs to show it to her 
mother - back again in a flash - and chattered away a little while until I was
glad to have her go; and then I sat by my window - and watched the sun
sink behind the mountains - watched the gilding of the clouds - watched the stars peek
out, and the mountains assume the deep blue color which they take as they lose themselves
in night;  watched the leaves on the few cottonwoods near the river shiver in
the cool mountain breeze - strained my eyes in watching till the tears came in
but every thought was of home.  I didn't see
the clouds, the hills, the stars nor trees; but
my pets at Racine - and I cried almost, and
for the first time I have allowed myself to do so since I left home.
I couldn't help it - I didn't think what I was about

When I began to challenge the little girl to speak to me.
When I woke up from my reverie, I went to church; at exactly nine o clock
by our hotel time the services began - and a full third of the congregation came
in after prayer.  There was quite as much style as in the M E church at Racine or
Aurora, the usual proportion of soldiers and as appreciation a congregation as I
ever saw.
A young Wisconsin man offered to see me home; he came to my room and only
went away as I began this.  The hours slip by very fast with me when I am
writing one has gone already, so I will go to bed assuring you that I love you
as ever and will add greatly to this tomorrow.
Always give my love to all who enquire after me.
Your Affectionate Husband
Simeon Whiteley

we have had sorrows, yet that none of them
have left Remorse behind, whose sting is
eternal torment.
Of my plans for the future, I am still
in the dark; but I borrow no trouble.
and look forward only with hope: hope less
clouded than any I have dared to entertain
for years and years. And I can assure
you now, as I have done at least
once before, that in the brightest picture
of the future which comes to my mind, 
glowing with all the beautiful colors
which "Hope, Sweet Hope" lend: there you are
the very, very centre of the scene. And
now don't laugh- but the vision which
comes to me oftenest is, seeing you in
the bright morning, mounted upon a 
beautiful pony, such as ladies ride here, 
dashing away, the plume in your
hat and your handkerchief waving
me a challenge to overtake you
as we start out from the "Agency"
on a frolic. O, we shall have
some gay, festive and innocent sprees
next summer - if all goes well. Meantime

Monday Morning May 25

And so I am no more to fancy I see you
in the old Sagetown house. I don't know how
to place you in the new one: you must
be very exact in your descriptions, for its
everything in thinking of home to be able
to place the "loved ones." I don't think then
that I shall ever be able to place you
any where else than in the little narrow
house which has at times been so chuck
full of happiness, and must ever be held 
sacred in Memory on account of the deep
griefs which we have suffered there. I am 
carried back, as I think of your leaving that house
to the time long, long- so far back! when you
looked at me so witchingly on the door
step, after blinding me almost with the snow
ball and all the way down to the present time,
the Panorama moves before me, jerking
its way along, now turning back- now
stopping to allow of the introduction of
side scenes; and when I come down to the
present time, after reviewing the whole,
there do I feel like praising God, that he has
been so good to us, and especially, that though

a lesson in stuffing birds. Take every
opportunity this summer to ride horse
back- you will need all your
experience when you get here.
Of course you need not be alarmed
about a supply of pine and spruce 
cones. But more anon- as
the chamber maid wants to do the 
work in my room.
Your husband
Simeon Whiteley.

In fast, I have come to look upon my

I go in the morning with Wisner to his

Nor does the primrose. When you come
we will press flowers in good shape

Denver, C. T.
                                                                                            May 20. 1863.

My Dear Wife:
I have just returned
from the Mountains, so near the
Range that the sunset at 3 P.M.
I am so full that I cannot
hold, but I cannot write more
before the mail closes.
I have two letters from
you which I shall open
as soon as I get this in

Denver, June 4, 1863.

My Dear Wife:
I have just written one
and a good share of another letter for the
"Advocate." I enclose the one completed,
but it needs some punctuation & c.
You must alter anything where the
language is bad- rewrite a whole
paragraph if necessary. It is awful
hard work for me to write now-a-days
except just when I am in the humor,
and then ten to one I am out of the
way of pen, ink & paper.
Yesterday I was so sleepy. I couldnt
write- today it is 90 in the shade. I
am not discommoded by the heat 
except drowsiness. I shall sleep under
three blankets to-night.
I had a good time at Wisners. He
is a little rough- would be called very
rough at Racine. His wife is as much
of a lady as she can be under the
circumstances- she is a real good
plain honest creature- and they
never quarrel. They have a boy of eight

My principal amusement at W's was
fishing, reading the back No's of the 
Atlantic, and after tea riding horseback. Jonthan
had just bought a new sidesaddle. I had
a good time, much better than I anticipated,
though I was sorry to be away'
from Church on Sunday. It was
not convenient to come here on Saturday.
On the way home I made seven
dollars by buying $40.00 Demand notes for $45.00 
legal tender, selling them today for $52.00.
That's my first "make."
I think it very safe to say that I 
shall be here or hereabouts for the
next three weeks; although the snow
has greatly diminished on the range
the past week. It is all gone off
the East and South side of Longs Peak
(except in deep Ravines)- even above the
timber line. We are waiting for 
certain authority from the circumlocution 
Office at Washington.
On my return from the mountains last
week. I had letters from the Haven's. Mrs. H.
said she had not heard from you

If you look at the Map you will see Long's
Peak- the St. Vrain River- perhaps the Boulder.
Wisner lives on the next claim to Titus of
Racine- the Boulder empties into the St.
Vrain on Titus' claim, just 30 miles
from the foot of Long's Peak and 30 miles
N.N.E of Denver. Longs is 1000 ft higher
than Pike's Peak- and a few hundred higher
than Mt. Shasta in California, which
until very recently has been supposed
to be the highest mountain in the
United States- But I must make
a newspaper letter of these
things. I was of course surprised
to run on to Titus so unexpectedly,
and equally so to find that
Lyman Dutton made his headquarters
there. I was just a couple of days too
late to see Lyman. Wisner calls him
self a Copperhead- but he says Titus is real
secesh- I didn't hear a good word
said of Titus but lots of the other sort,
principally about his deal. I will
write Perry in a few days more
about Lyman.

since the very pleasant visit'
at Bills'. If you have a
mind to, drop her a line and

this, when printed. They don't know

go to Europe with Dr. Dyer. 
Perhaps to Washington. Dr. Haver never 
knows any more than other folks
what he is going to do a month ahead.
I think perhaps the next two letters. I
should like to have sent to them. 
Address Box 510 Chicago. It will find

shall write them as soon as I

from our folks east. I will write

to Mother before I do any thing else

after my newspaper letters.
I have to begin with the Chicago

all my other expected "arrangements"

I suppose judge Jones wrote you a note.
He said he was going to. Fifteen new

I guess I asked too much- for you

which goes with me everywhere and

Dont you think I am getting tough, to

I get some compliments for sitting

Did you read "Happy Days"- in the

There are several other matters

With kindest love to all
I am darling- as ever
Your Affectionate Husband
Simeon Whiteley.
