Monday Evening
                                                                                                              June 1st 1863. 8 P.M.

My Dear Wife:
I have just come in with
Wisner, on horseback- 30 miles. Am a 
little tired. The mail closes in a half hour,
and is nearly half a mile away. I have
got three letters from you in my pocket
unopened as yet. This is Wisner's Post Office
and I haven't heard a word of news for
the week I have been away, but had
a good time nevertheless.
Much more by the next
mail from
Your Affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley.

Denver, CT June 9, 1863.

My Dear Wife;
I didn't get any letter from
you by the mail today- and indeed had no
reason to expect one, as I had not been
slighted by the two preceeding mails; but
some how or other I should have felt a little
better in my idleness. How in the world
I manage to pass the time in Denver
is a mystery; somehow I find time to do
a good deal of writing, but I dont see
that it amounts to much when written.
I really feel ashamed of the newspaper
letters I have mailed, even though Gov
Bangs has began to re-print them.
But this won't last long now. Very
soon I shall have but a poor chance
to write at all, and may be I shall
be very glad of a chance to come to
Denver once in a while.
Today we received our expected 
instructions from Washington- yesterday
I accepted the offer of an interpreter,
all that is waiting now for a start is

I went to church twice, and went to see the
Gov who was sick. Mrs. Gov. wasn't visible,
neither had she been to Sabbath School as usual;
but I could hear her reading to Willie. I hear
it said on every hand that "she has endeared her
self to the people here very much"- and think I
shall like her much better than I thought I
should from what Mrs. Haver said of her.
I havent answered Mrs H's letter yet,
but I must. I am waiting for that slip
of yours before writing to Roderick C.
Wrote a long letter to Mother by last
Mail and one to Perry. While I was
writing to Perry, Lyman was in town,
but I did not know it until afterward.
On Monday evening I spent some
two hours with Mr. Ludlow- author of the
"Hachesh Eater" ( a book that I have read about
a great deal)* and Mr. Beerstadt, a Boston
Artist, with a Norwegian or Danish name.
This was at the house of Surveyor Genl Pierce,
I found his wife a rather pleasant woman
very plain- a good deal of fun in her. 
and from there, I bea?ed]] home an elderly lady
of English descent. I knew she was of

Hasheesh Eater, by Fitz Hugh Ludlow

arrival of Maj. Head, from whom I expect
to obtain my team & c. A fortnight more!
I have an invitation to join a large
party who are going over the range
next week on a pleasure excursion. One
of the editors with his family and some
other lady friends- who are all right.
Another invitation reached me today
to be one of a party to scale Long's 
Peak, which last I have accepted on
condition that I have the time - it
comes off in two weeks. Very few people
have been up there. It is hardly likely
that I shall be here then.
I am inpatient for the Atlantic for June,
which for some cause is behind. I have
read up everything.
We had terribly hot weather last week.
People say they never experienced the like here.
- it was like Washington in August- and
I lay uncovered all night. Old settlers
say they never saw the snowy range so
bare before.
Last Saturday I spent nearly two hours
at Mr. Millard's, very pleasantly; on Sunday

English descent, because she said she
was born in Liverpool, but "she was
very young." I suppose she intended
to add "when she came to this country."
From examining pictures at Pierces', I found
that Mrs. P was a sort of cousin of Dr. Haver,
and knew him well.
We are in hopes that you have the news of
the capture of Port Hudson and will soon
have that of Vicksburg. What a horrible
war this is! But there is no other way
than to fight it through- as the Rebs seem
determined to hold out to the last.
You of course know that the Col Kilpatrick
is the one who boarded at Mrs. Drinkards. He
and the Eight Ill. have been doing good service.
You wont expect a long letter today,
I know- and so assuring you that I love
you more than ever- I will close
Your Affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley.

Denver, Monday A. M. June 15/63.

My Dear Wife:
I generally get a letter by
Monday's mail, but the coach has not
yet arrived and probably will not come
until afternoon;  the weather has been
so very - and as they all say here- so
unusually hot, that the drivers go
as slow as the schedule allows.
I wouldnt begin to write now
until the mail comes in- for I never
feel like writing when just expecting
a letter from you- only I know that
by afternoon, the sun will shine upon
my side of the house, and having
no Venetian to protect, shall be driven
out of my room by the excessive
heat; and I find too, that I cannot see
to either read or write in the middle
of the day.
On Saturday last after some
experiments, we could not find a place where
the thermometer would get down below

as usual.  A week ago last night Brother Willard attempted to prove that
God was not the author of Evil, nor was he responsible for it in any way or
shape, and he promised that evening he would tell us who was &c.
But at the outset, he had the honesty to come out and tell us that it was a 
Great Mystery - and he couldn't solve it.
During the week I asked him if he had read "Bitter Sweet."  He said
he had, and quoted lots of it; he was
very much taken up with it when in College at Evanston, and had
written a very elaborate article or review for the College paper - but now he
renounced it as miserable doctrine.
Of course I was greatly interested to hear what he would have to
say, but the only real point he made was that
"God seeks for virtue - not for Innocence."
My opinion is, that he will yet, have to come back to the idea that David
expressed.  "That Evil lives, and not - against his

102, and this is the climate where, I was 
told that I did not need any thin clothing.
But I must confess after all, that I 
don't suffer as at the East where there is more moisture in the atmosphere.
Perhaps however, this may be partially on account of my improved health.
People down from the mountains report it was very pleasant weather with them.
By the bye there is a terrible fire raging in the mountains about fifty
miles away between us and the point where the sun sinks at night;
the volume of smoke is immense, and the generally gorgeous sunset scene
is greatly increased in splendor.  
We see but little of the blaze as other mountains shut out the ground view;
else we should have a nightly illumination.
There is no stopping these fires - and as there are no people in the way
no one would attempt to even if it were possible.
I attended church twice yesterday

will, else He is subject, and we have
instead of God - a phantom nothing with a phantom name.
The Episcopal Bishop was here yesterday and six clergymen were
within the chancel - in a building which will not - hold more than 200.
Among the clergy is a Mr. DeMora a Spaniard, who has suffered
much in Spain on account of his Religious and political opinions.
Of course our congregation was slim, but we had some good singing.
I am just getting so that I can sing; at first I couldn't take air enough
into my lungs.
There is an Elgin lady on the way - expected this week - a Miss Hewitt,
sister in law of Charles Morgan of whom you have heard me speak
at least.  There is a young man here by the name of France.
There is a little house here, being neatly finished.  I think Bro. Willard will be
needed very soon after young ladies'

arrival - and I am to be there.
Young man is a little impatient, but he looks happy.  Haven't seen the
young lady for three years.  I have seen her picture - also a large
parquet of letters with a female handwrite upon the envelope of
each.  Beautiful isn't it?  
I hope that my Longs Peak expedition will not collide with this little quiet affair.
Willard and wife have not been married very long you know.
She likes the country - likes housekeeping and doing her own work,
and living in our half of a house not big enough for six persons.
You remember that Roderick says "Mr C., is very contented and 
likes the country very much."
I suppose it is hard to conceive a more disagreeable climate than
at Virginia City.  What a singular influence Love Conjugal has upon

Our bookseller's package of Atlantic's 
has been lost on the way, and I am so impatient for it;
especially the article upon "Spring at the Capital" where you should have been.
if___ And now I am promising myself that you will be with me here next Spring!
How little we know of what may be!  But darling whatever may be; when I see so
much infelicity in the world, I am thankful every day that it is as well
with us as it is.  I long - oh, how I long -
Tut!  Tut! - that's forbidden and I drive back, back, back to
their source those longings which to give vent to would only make
the days so sad - and I have other duty.
But I love you nevertheless as a true woman that I know you
are loves to be loved.  Be sure of this - ever - always sure; and let 
sweet Hope for better, still better days keep tears away.
Your Affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley

grows very thrifty, the only sign of vegetation for blocks near her house,
and yet I bet you that Mrs Lincoln with that beautiful lawn and fountain - the
Potomac and Potomac shore - her Conservatory, and the thousand flowing

I  read on Saturday and yesterday Edwin Brothertoft, by Maj. Theodore Winthrop.

Denver. June 18. 1863.

My Dear Wife:
I was so glad that you
celebrated the 6th in so appropriate a
manner. I knew that you would if
you had time. I have no idea
that you are going to find much
fault with me on the score of
letter-writing even if this is a short
one- for one thing or another has made
me fool away the day completely.
until now it is sun down and
the mail closes at nine o'clock
not to leave again until Tuesday
morning, and this is Friday.
As i sit at my window, I can
see all the glory of the sunset
scene.
I enclose you a few more
flowers. The Larkspur grows even
more rank in these Mountains
than about the Whitehouse the Milk

here. At first with very poor prospect,

a good deal of late." Willard is working

of a Seminary upon his hands. Of
course he meets with opposition.
"Sectarianism" is the cry, but he is

I mail with this a letter to
the Chicago Tribune

of strawberries by the time you

party has "busted" for the present.
It will not take me long to

But I cannot see any more.
As ever
Simeon Whiteley.

June 24 1863

My Dear Wife
Instead of writing you the long letter which I had intended to yesterday,
I had to start off on an errand for the Governor to an Indian encampment
some twelve miles below.
I had a good time - I Wish you could have been along - there
were some two hundred lodges with their squaw papooses & c - the
squaws couching on their hands and knees would peep out of their teepees
the pappooses would run after our carriage laughing and yelling How!  How
How!
The chiefs are now coming in to have a "talk" with the governor who is "Heap Chief white man!"
They are Arapahoes

this afternoon I start off to meet a band of Utes and stop over night at 
Trisners?.
Mr. Thorpe of Racine arrived here yesterday morning.  I found him on 
my return home.  He goes to the mountains this morning and will
return in a week - by the time I get back.
I got your letter with Mrs, B's picture - and considering the
others she has had - it is first rate.
It gives one an idea that she is not quite as homely as sin and Death.
Mr. Allen disappointed me in his Sundays discourse.
This trip keeps me busy in preparing, until the time to start and
so I must bid you good bye for a time.
Cannot tell how long, exactly 
As ever - affectionately.  Simeon Whiteley

Denver, June 29, 1863

My Dear Wife:
My trip did not last so long you see, as I anticipated.
Was only gone three days instead of seven - had a nice time,
two good horses, nice "Ambulance" carriage - good roads - a stop over
one night at miners - made plenty of acquaintances - pleasant ones -
fished some and caught nothing -had plenty of beautiful trout
to appease splendid appetites - and visited one of the most beautiful
portions of the mountain range; failed to find any Utes - but calmed the fears of the people,
bot back to Denver in season to spend Sunday here.
Today Maj Head arrived; I like him exceedingly well.  I have
been entertaining him to day, and so came very near being
cheated out of time to write to

away without seeing the boy.  I used to write you from
Washington that I got along with my superiors.  Well, my
relations with Gov. Evans grow better and better every day, and I 
am by no means sorry that I came out here; not a bit of it.
I can see something ahead here.  I bought a pair of gloves the
other day - and that is the first cent I have expended except for
board and the Sunday collection in the month of June.
I sold that black coat for $10 00 last week, which is just what I paid
for it more than two years since.
My health is better than I ever enjoyed since I remember.  My cheecks
are round and hard, the crease which shows in my picture has gone.
Your letter of the 18th came this morning - and found the big one

at all, but he has gone to his camp.  I am learning very fast.
Shall be off very soon now.
I think next Monday at furthest.
He and his Utes have been very much pleased of course.  He had
not been East since 1846, himself.  He says that the stories
in the papers that one of his men talked saucy to the President
are all false.  He says that Maj Colley who took the Cheyannes, Kiowas
and Camanches, had a great deal of trouble with him, and will never want to
go to Washington again; but he says, we have the best, the manliest tribe
of Indians on this Continent.
Gov. Evans is feeling first rate to-day.  His boy is doing well for a three day old.
Mrs. E was very sick yesterday, but is comfortable today though she denies visitors.
I was down to the house to see the Governor today, but had to come

when I got home.  Will write Sayrs in a day or two.
The "Happiest Days" was in the January No. of the Atlantic.  I mean to send
you a little money soon.  We must be very careful now.  We will leave
the "good time" when I come home again.  I have no doubt but I shall
be in Racine before I have been away a year, and have some
plans in my head, which if they can be carried out, will please you:
"I live for those who love me 
For those who know me true."
Can fix no dates for coming or going yet; or perhaps until the time.
I am reading "Gail Hamiltons" Book Country Living and Country Thinking" Kate
would like the article entitled "Men and Women."
I had intended to warn you against anything in the papers about an Indian War
with the Utes.  If it takes place it will not be with my lands or in Colorado.  The Utes extend
over several hundred miles of territory - ours are at peace.
In the dark - as ever.
Simeon

Middle Park
                                             Sunday night
                                             July

Dear Wife:
I am having a great time.  Plenty of adventure already.
Slept out of doors several nights but I cannot write you here.
I write this by the light of the camp fire.
Would have written you a long letter to-day
had I expected this opportunity to send you a letter.
I am in first rate health.  Haven't shaved in eight or ten days
and the boys say I look some rough.
I dressed up today

however in a clean shirt collar.
I cannot tell how far I may go this time, or
how soon I shall have an opportunity of sending you
another letter.  Have had no word from you since a week 
ago Friday.  Am afraid I shall lose some of your letters 
in my efforts to have them reach me:
Rains every day and night showers O.
the mountains!  But this park is not Paradise
to any person who has lived in Illinois or Wisconsin.
Goodbye for this time
Your husband
Simeon Whiteley

Denver July 6, 1863.
My Dear Wife:
Last week was a rather interesting week with us in charge of Indian affairs.
On Monday as I wrote you Maj Head arrived with his Ute chiefs, and with
him and them I had a good time visiting.  The red skins were rightly
important on account of having seen the President; and come back
fully determined to do all in their power to keep peace between their
people and the whites.  Everything they saw gratified them.
Lincoln they call "Great and Good;"
The railroads and steamboats of course were great wonders -
but when asked what they considered the most wonderful they 
answered - the Rail Road Ferry at Havre de Grace (which you will
recollect) and the Suspension Bridge at Niagara; the Falls themselves
they did not consider any very great

not get a letter off for you on Friday for which I have felt very sorry
ever since, but it was almost unavoidable.
Well you say:  "Now Simmy will be off very soon."  Perhaps so.  We shall see.
Mrs. Evans and son are getting along very satisfactorily; especially when the
hot weather is considered; the thermometer indicating in the vicinity of
90 from breakfast to tea time for several days past in the shade.
About a week since there was a fresh fall of snow upon the Range
which lasted for a day or two, but that is gone, and the west French trader
says he never saw so little snow upon the mountains.  It is
very hard even here to realise, that ice forms 3/4 of an inch thick nearly
every night within a days horseback ride of us.
On Saturday the Fourth of July occurred.  All the forenoon I was

things.  They left here on Thursday morning for the Conejos (con-a-os) Agency, which
is in the San Louis Valley - 250 miles hence, and immediately west of the
Spanish Peaks.  For the Agent I conceived a very high regard and
how mutual it was you may guess when he told me, that if
I ever wanted his assistance, he would come any time - as he
thought it no hardship to ride 200 or 400 miles.  He speaks both
Ute and Mexican apparently with the same facility that he does
English.  His Utes also speak Mexican freely - although only two of the seven
spoke but very rarely.
Loree the other Agent arrived on Tuesday, and Dr. Ketcham - the 
Medicine Man who vaccinates - was to leave with him; so the Governors
Indian business kept him very busy.
Sometimes until twelve o clock at night.
On Thursday and Friday I was busy assisting him, so that I did

trying to find the coolest spot.  But afternoon I was impressed into a 
horseback ride with Mr. Bartlett of whom I have spoken before, (and 
who strange to say was a warm personal friend of John Harvey, up in Waupacca Co)
a Mrs. Nolan, an English lady who has lived several years in Australia, at Melbourne and vicinity,
and a Miss Sopris, one of the teachers in the public school. a young lady who
has a sister who hopes some day to be the daughter in law of Mr. Haddock, who
is in the Com. Genls office at Washington - while she herself -rather expects to be the
wife of the Mr. Cushman that Sayers wrote to me about.
He rode about thirteen miles after three o clock and found it hot enough -
Before tea which we took at the house of a friend.  Bartlett and
myself took a delicious bath in Bear Creek in water not two feet deep - but very swift
and at sundown started back.  The Twilight lasted an hour and a quarter, and just as
that gave way to night, the spot where

the moon would rise was very clearly indicated - but it did not rise
for still another hour, by which time we arrived in Denver.
We had splendid animals to ride - the only trouble being that mine - a large
sized Indian Pony  danced, and fretted to go too fast, and although I had on Buckskin gloves,
in my efforts to hold him my ring cut my finger so that it seems as if it would be sore a 
long time unless the ring comes off, and that can only be done by cutting it.
I expect to buy that Pony today (on account of the U.S. of course) and
I guess he won't dance quite so hard after I have been over the 
mountains a week or two.  He is a roan - if he was only Black I should
want to buy him for myself as it is he is a beauty of a roan.
Well, although I was not stiffened as horseback riding used to make
me, yet being out in the sun affected

the wedding by my trip northward last week, but I enclose the card.
I want you to get the Atlantic regularly to read - if in no other way, buy it and give
it to Mary.  If you must borrow money to get along do so, but I shall send you
some very soon, when it is convenient to get a draft on Chicago.
Greenbacks are at a premium of five per cent on New York Exchange; having gone up from
three to five since I came.  Last year, N.Y Exchange was at a premium of five over greenbacks.
The gold mines are making a better show every day.  Thorpe 
has not come down from the mountains yet.  I expected him last Thursday.
When our mint gets established, the Government will finish Greenbacks 
for "Retort" in abundance.  As it is now - the premium on Gold more
than pays all the expenses of mining in well established Lodes.
You did not tell me the name of the man who gave father the iron pyrites.

me so that although Bishop Ames occupied the pulpit, I did not get
out to church yesterday morning.  But I heard him last evening.
I do not like him so well as Simpson, but he had the little church
full you can be assured.
So prompt was the Bishop and so tardy the Congregation and Choir, that Capt. M Lane and
myself had to do a good share of the singing of the 1st hymn.  He preached

I think I wrote you that I missed

Today I shall mail a paper to Father in which I shall enclose a couple of heads of
rye, which are considered a fair average of the field.
My papers do not come very regularly.  Last week we had a 
wet mail:  your letters came all right, but there were some so
defaced that the address could not be read.  I wonder if any
of them were for me.  Besides your letters I have had two from Perry
a double one from the Havers - one from Father at Madison 
and one from Doctor Lieb; except official letters, that is my stock since coming
here as near as I can recollect - and so perhaps the wet mail was mostly
for me.  I should like to see it rain in Denver once!
If the weather will cool off, I will write a letter for the Tribune.  Haven't
seen my two last to the Advocate yet.
Perhaps I shall get another letter from you today: by that time it will be too
hot to write more, but you shall hear again soon -
From your Affectionate Husband
Simeon Whiteley.

The Middle Park Indian Agency,
COLORADO TERRITORY

                                                                                                          Denver. July 8th 1863

My Dear Wife:  The coach is not in yet, and may not be until afternoon but just
having been over to the Printing office I am constrained to sit down now
to write you a few lines, before the sun gets around so as to 
slice upon my room window, after which it would be no use to 
attempt to remain to write.
On yesterday I received the Advocate with my first Mountain letter in - the
only one I have written for the paper which was well written, but they have
mangled and torn it so with bad punctuation, spelling, and so forth, that
I inwardly determined not to submit any more to the same cruel treatment.
I got the Democrat, and Beacon at the same time.  On Monday I received two
letters from you - one of June 3rd - one of the 25th

first thing is to sit down to write you a letter; you can judge somewhat what my reverie was about.
But it makes me feel bad not to have Dele love to sleep with you or I, as well as she does with Father.
The big Indian Expedition which I mentioned last week has been ordered to return; Gen. Connor telegraphing
that all the trouble was over.  So I shall have plenty of troops to accompany me.
On Saturday, I leave Denver for Idahoe and Empire - to go off
on a little excursion into the mountains where few men have travelled.
Wm H Russell and Gen Peirce are to be of the party.
Without returning to Denver I shall take Curtis, my Interpreter and go over to the Park.
Perhaps I shall not be able to write to you quite so frequently there
for a time.  But you will know that I love you.

The one of the 3d contained a good deal of little house news which I wanted
to know.  You can send "Gold Foil" whenever they get it, I want a copy to keep.
Pretty good for Winslow.
When I send you some more money I want you to make me a half dozen
white shirts, at least, after the pattern we got in New York.
I am going to write Jos. Jackson to make me a pair of fine boots too.
I am afraid I have at last spoiled my Gold pen.  I let it fall into my
wash bowl on Monday night - wash bowl on the floor.  Don't see but
I write as good as before with it, but I have to hold it differently.
Last evening I played Euchre at Gen Pierces' house, went to bed about 
eleven - woke up about sunrise and lay in the most delightful reverie
until seven - then took a bath.
It was delicious - so you see the

I shall try to get your letters sent to me frequently - if I conclude to
stay very long; but shall not be very anxious for telegraph news,
unless it grows better.  I do not write much about the war in my letters
not because I feel any less interest than formerly,
but it is so useless to speculate.
I do want to "holler" once good.
If our army of the Potomac cannot whip Lee now - they never will.
I see by the Beacon that Howland died in Hospital.  Am very glad to
hear of Mrs. Heywoods expectancy.
Mrs. Evans is quite low again.
Since I wrote you before, I have had still greater proof of the Govs friendship
and close confidence.
I received Sayers' letter.  He shall hear from it as soon as I can write satisfactorily.
With Kindest love to all
Your Affectionate Husband
Simeon Whiteley

July 10th 1863

My Dear Wife:
Yesterday I gave up to rejoicing over the news from the Army of the Potomac which
you had to celebrate the 4th with.  Today we have additional
news from Vicksburg but I am too busy to indulge.  I have
just bought an outfit for our Expedition.  I leave here in the morning if possible.
I leave Empire next Thursday but whether I shall be able to write
you for two or three weeks I cannot tell.
I enclose you a draft on the Depy at Chicago for $75.00 
but I cannot too earnestly commend economy.  Recollect that I may not always have

I can write no more now, only give you once again the 
assurance of my undying love for you - and that the dearest
hope I have in life is for the time to come when we can
sit down together, once again in our own nice little quiet
cottage.  It will come.
Your Affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley

as good a situation as this and we may value a dollar
then for bread and butter as much as we do ten now.
I don't ever want to have you dependent upon your 
father for bread and butter as in 1859.
I am in excellent spirits, and thank you from the bottom
of my heart for your most excellent letter of the 28th which
came this morning - the winter green enclosed with taste and
smell all right.
I grow sad when I think of the bloodshed - but really hope
that the rebs will yield before long.  They must feel terribly
discouraged.  Copperheads must too.  I almost expect to hear
that Charley Juvette is killed this time.

The Middle Park Indian Agency,
COLORADO TERRITORY

                                   July 23 5 a.m. 1863.

My Dear Wife: 
A man has just
woke me up to say that
he will take any letters to
the other side of the Mountains
I can have ready immediately.
We are at the Springs which
are not so beautiful to look
upon as I expected but other
wise a great institution I am
most terribly disappointed in
this Park, which is most
desolate in appearance.
We have plenty of game and
are having good times. I have
not received a letter from
you since two weeks tomorrow.
Expect several to-morrow
night or Saturday.

Have just heard of the
fall of Port Hudson.
My kindest love
to all.
In great haste
Your affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley

The Middle Park Indian Agency,
COLORADO TERRITORY.

Denver Aug 1   1863

My Dear Wife:  I received a letter from you last Friday, and another to-day; just a week
I wanted to write you on Wednesday but the mail bought me nothing and so I waited.
But how can I write with the thermometer indicating 103 in the shade - a half an
hour ago 105; and now the sun shines square upon the window of my room;
and if I wait until  evening, my letter will not leave until next Tuesday morning.
I have just written an offhand sort of a letter to Perry which will accompany this - as one
from him came with yours, in which he says "Saw Jane yesterday.  
she looks as beautiful as ever."
I leave for the mountains again on Monday morning.  Curtis and the squaw will then start out in search

rolled down the mountain side, knocking down loose rock and
young pine trees; where the sack of brown sugar 2/3ds full rolled down nearly
a quarter of a mile!  You can hardly realize now how fearfully 
funny it was to see them roll.
We have a good trail now made by the soldiers.
I had a letter from Madison today.  He proposes that when I get
through here, that I provide for his comfort, and then asks:
"Suppose I write to John Walken my son-in-law" to let me come
and live with him; I am too old 
to work the land. &c
John writes that mother grows more feeble, and begins to think of her end
being near.
Mr. Tilton's place is at work for a church.  He deemed me for $100 00 this

morning. -  I took pity on Mrs. Willard whos photographs were spoiling for
want of an Album, and took her up one which cost $6 00; it will hold
thirty six.  But for the present I don't go anything on the new church - especially
as Willard is now Presiding Elder, and I don't know who is 
coming - but some popular young man from Chicago.  There is great
strife between the M.E, Presbyterian and Episcopal churches here as to who
shall take the lead.  The Episcopalians  who have a stick for a Priest have
just added a pine board extension to their neat little office - putting it on
the side and spoiling it, at a greater cost than a new building - and they
feel bad.  The Presbyterians have begun the brick walls for a church
only 2/3ds the size of the M E structure proposed, and which is to be done by
the 1st of January.

I had know I should remain here so long.  Some Union League business
has occupied my time considerably for a week.  My purchases for food 
are made including 6 cans Peaches, 10 green corn, 10 tomatoes - all put up in
Baltimore.  I picked a half dozen strawberries in the Park - as many Raspberries - as good as 
Red Antwerp this side the Range - At Empire had a dish of the latter for
tea; there I saw two ragged looking young women with large pails full of their
own picking.  Was told their names was Peck - and that two years since
they lived next door to the Burche's on Mich. Ave Chicago.
My  relations with Gov. Evans grow in the right direction - and he is all
right with the people here.  Will Colorado be admitted?  If so all right.
I hope to be able to get a good share of my subsistence paid by Dept. including

There will be empty benches in some of them when they are all done.
I go away before receiving the word from Washington about the Treaty.
But the San Louis Valley, or Ute treaty cannot be held before Nicolay will
have to return.  I feel certain.
Now if father can fix it with Senator Doolittle it would be nice.
If Father cannot come, well no matter.
My new pen goes better - and does first rate for small writing.
I forgot to tell you that we had a heavy shower in Denver last Sunday
afternoon - it lasted five minutes and laid the dust for two homes.  So much
rain has not fallen in Denver, all told, in the four months I have been here.
I wrote to Rod Chappell this week - and a line to Charley Jewitt,
which would have been two, if

my hotel bills here in Denver.  Gov has approved my accounts for them.
My other expenses are very light, never were less.  I want a home - a home.-
I am enjoying life here pretty well - I make the agency 
yield all it is worth in fear - but I do want a home- this separation
must cease before long.
I think myself you have too much company - and too little time to read
or solitude for reflection.  I have got the June July & Aug. Atlantics' to take along.
Give my love to all the friends who come to see you.  I hear nothing more 
from Sayers.  Nothing at all from father or Mary direct, but then, you know
I love them all - and you more than all. - If I hadn't forgot how
I would send kisses for Delia.
Goodbye Darling
Your husband
Simeon Whiteley.

Sunday Eve  Aug 9th  1863

My Dear Wife:  Tomorrow morning and I'm once more on my winding way.  
Tomorrow night, pony and I will be at Empire - 46 miles, the next day cross the
"Range" and reach the soldiers camp - 20; and Wednesday noon at the Springs.
On Thursday, I hope to start Curtis' Miss "Lol" and a guide in search of the
people of this Agency, leaving me, out of doors, with such company as may happen
to be there - or come along.
My tent, books, writing material may not reach me until next Sunday. Yesterday I 
ordered a cabinet marker to make me a stand and stool - only not
to put them together - and with a bottle of Spauldings glue I expect to have, with
the exception of Capt. Bonesteels camp chair the first piece of furniture in all
that county.

shut out of sight by the clouds, and except at noon when it was sultry for an
hour, the day has been delightfully cool.
I went to church this morning to hear Mr. Slaughter and liked the
last half of his sermon very much.
At the recent conference.  Bro William was made Presiding Elder, and nearly
all the main points were left to be supplied.  The Bishop said he should
go to Evanston, then look over the list of graduates and send five
of the most promising out of the lot.  With the energy displayed
by our Methodist friends here, the other folks will have to stir
their boots to keep up.  I most earnestly wish them success - but you
know that I believe that Methodism is any better passport to the 
"goodly land in view" but I don't care how much energy they put in.
There never was a fairer field

Then perhaps I can write you, an occasional long letter.
We have dispatches from Washington authorizing Gov. Evans to fix
time of treaty in the San Louis Valley - and it is to be the 3d week
in September in the hope of accommodating Nicolay; but we 
cannot tell whether that will suit him or not; so I shan't be able
to post father about it at all.
Gov. Evans gold running operations are just now giving him great satisfaction.
The new machinery is just beginning to work to advantage.
Mrs. Evans is beginning to ride out regularly.
Passengers on the coach this afternoon report that they came 
through continuous rain - all day, until within nine miles
of Denver.  here the dust is very deep.  The mountains have been

for Missionary work than here in Colorado - and if I was a Methodist preacher at the East,
I would give some rousing missionary sermons in its behalf.  A very large proportion
of the present population have had more or less religious training, many of them "more" the
worst part of the population was largely depleted by the rush to the 
"New Mines" last spring.  When I came here nearly all the stores
were open on Sunday - to-day only the Jew shops were open.
I have not seen more than five drunken men to-day - four months
since it would have been from one to three hundred; and the
change is remarkable.  So if you get talking to any of our
Preachers, you may tell them that I

say that $100 00 Missionary money spent here, in this territory - will do more
towards hastening the Millenium than $1.000.000 00 in the East Indias,
and charity begins at home.  All it needs is laborers, and they will
all be self-supporters in six months.
There is money enough here - only get the people in the habit of using
it in the right direction.  Work on the Seminary is begun.  Slaughter says
the new church is a sure thing by the first of January.
This afternoon I read the proceedings of the Laymens Convention
in New York, clear through Bishop Simpson is a great man, and no mistake.
Tonight, I spent some time in the parlor - singing with Capt. M C
Lane, of the Coloradobols.  We had a moderately good time.
When we got through it was too late to go to church, much to my regret.

creases so much faster on their docket than they dispose of it that every
day on adjournment they sing a parody on the verse commencing
"When we've been there then thousand years"
When Joseph Jackson sends in the boots I ordered, you had as well send
him the money.  Keep a mem. of all you pay out on my account.
I wish you would send me a black silk neck tie, if you have the stuff handy,
double thickness of the silk with no stuffing - and plain.  You can put
that in a letter.  My shirts & c can remain subject to order - or
opportunity to send.  Perhaps I can get along until I come home.
But I must go to bed - so as to be up and doing in the morning.
Goodnight darling
Your Affectionate Husband
Simeon Whiteley

Tomorrow is mail day, and the question is: "if I wait until it arrives will I have
a letter from you or will I not."  With the probabilities in favor of the negative,
although the cool of the morning will be passed, I shall wait the chances.
Among the arrival to day at the Fremont House, were Mr & Mrs. Frank Cramp
of New England; the lady was lifted upstairs on her bed.
I think I wrote you that Capt. Johnson of this Battery was here on
Court Martial: he is the brother of Cass. Jones widow: well he has been
relieved and a miserable set of charges preferred against him.  Little bits of
peccadilloes.  Of course they are not proven; but he is quite sick over
it; though he sits about the hotel.  The officers seem to be in
a nice wrangle among themselves, for the business of the Court in

COLORADO TERRITORY.

                        Sunday Ev. Aug 16 1863.

My Dear Wife. I am in camp at the
Springs again, this is the 4th day. My
tent, table and writing materials are
behind. This is my last envelope save
one, and some of paper. My provisions
are here, just come the other things may
not reach me until I am ready to
return. Curtis and the squaw went
westward on Friday. I have a Mr.
Campbell here camping with me.
I caught some trout yesterday, and shot
a grouse on the wing and a Jack
Rabbit ( I think I have described this 
animal to you before) on the run. I am
so disappointed about the delay of just
the articles with which to make camp
life cozy that I don't feel first rate 
tonight. The freighter didnt have sense
enough to bring the latest papers, so that
we are just a week behind Denver, and

ten days behind Racine, with the prospect
of being six more days without. I have
a little willow house which is now shedding
the rain which is falling sharply, with a 
fair prospect for a rainy night. Capt.
Bonesteen has brought his company down to
the springs last Monday. Capt. B is from Milwaukee The boys enjoy
it hugely, have built a foot bridge across
the river and catch on an average, he 
says, about 500 lb trout daily. They had
preaching to-day, but I did not know of it
until too late. have been cleaning up
camp, cooking and washing dishes nearly
all day, reading a Chicago Trib. of July 14 which was
exceedingly interesting. We have all the wild game
we want. The Mountains were afire last
night illumining the whole region. I begin
to like the Park, much better than I thought
I should at first. It is a great relief from
the heat of Denver. Am afraid I shall
have trouble again with my mail, as
more came to-day. Will try and get some
paper and write you more at length.
Your affectionate husband, Simeon

The Middle Park Indian Agency,
COLORADO TERRITORY.

                       Hot Sulphur Springs
                               Aug 22   1863.

My Dear Wife;
I have saved this half sheet
with great care, it is the last possitively.
When I shall get any more, I cannot tell.
The envelope I raised of a traveller, his
last.
I have only time to say before he
goes that I am well and hearty.
I leave this camp for Denver on the 18th
of Sept. I have no letters since I
came here. Shall have a mail next
Tuesday-29th. Perhaps I do want a letter
from you. I had to leave Denver after all
before the coach came, but last night I got Racine
papers which came that day, but no letters.
But I cannot write more now, and
when you will hear from me again, the
Lord only knows, but I guess within a
week after this. Goodbye darling
Simeon Whiteley

Grand Sulphur Springs
                                                                      Aug 27, 1863
                                                                                9 P.M.

My Dear Wife,
For five days past, I was
poor enough. Mr. Campbell was here
but all else, even my pony was
gone. Last night pony came back
brought one letter from you;
then came Mr. Elbert Secy of the
Territory, Mr. Nicolay, the President's 
Secy., Mr Byers, Editor of the "News",
Surveyor Genl Pierce
Mr. Hawkins, who came here with
me on my first visit. Then
Maj Downing came to inspect
the troops, and Dr. Hamilton an
Army Surgeon, who I this evening
discovered assisted Dr. Brainard?
operate on our Harvey. Well of
course we have had a jolly
good day. Elbert brought me
two more letters from you

and every body sent me
lots of papers.
All the party leave to-morrow
except Nicolay who
expects to camp with me
until Sept.10, when I go to
Denver. Then he goes
to Conejos after ten days
in Denver. He rather enjoys
the idea of the delay, so then
you see we dont want father
to come. 
I cannot tell when I
shall be home, until the 
convention is closed, but my chances
for being in Racine on the 26th
is very poor. Gov. talks of my not
going until Spring.
But I do love you and will be
home as soon as I can. I can
not write more now as every body
is coming to bed. Five of us laying about 
as close as need be.

I have borrowed a razor to-night,
my tent hasnt come and I
dont expect it- every thing
else behind that I needed
for comfort. I write this
on my knee.
Your affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley

The Middle Park Indian Agency,
COLORADO TERRITORY.

                   Sep 17. (Denver) 1863.

My Darling Wife: I have been here 
in Denver about 48 hours, after one
of the most glorious trips a man ever
made; but how tired I was! We made
the North Park a visit, and came
over the "Range" by a new "Pass", not
much of a "pass" either for we were
three miles where the wind blew
so we had to hold on by our
hair,- being at least 1000 feet above
the timber line; we could see the
Western Boundary of the Park- seventy
five miles away at least, and by
facing eastward- twice as far
(perhaps) on the Plains.
The Parks are no longer grey and
grave looking; I never witnessed such
a metamorphosis. Foot hills which a
month since looked black and dismal
had been changed by the hand of Jack

Tomorrow we are invited to a 
dinner party at Mr. Byer's farm.
Mrs. Gov and baby are said to be
doing well, and Mrs. Willard has
a two weeks old baby, and I never
suspected. This is a great county.
A Mr. Daniel De Fore (or some
such name- my pencil mark is lost)
was accidentally killed lately. He was
from Racine, Lyman Dutton told me, 
and I saw a notice of it in the
papers, asking Racine papers to
copy. 
Judge Jones writes me that
John Barraclough left $90.00 to
be given to me.
Letter from Rod Chappell I
enclose.
I have had a great treat this
week- Seven letters from you.
If I get time I will answer
some of the questions in detail
before going South- west.

Frost into the most charming
spots your eyes ever rested
upon. Nicolay said they were
"vast pieces of richest embroidery."
I called them the "birth places of
Rainbows."
I can now realize the
enthusiasm with which people
used to talk to me of "The Park."
But of all this more when 
I see you.
Yesterday I rested, and had a 
room full of company all day.
To-day I have been busy with
my accounts- busy as a bee-
and I am resting a little while
to write this little letter, for if
we start Monday. I shall have
to jump;
The Gov. has not returned
however from his Republican Fork
Treaty. Nicolay is having the
fidgets about it.

Get the deed recorded, of course-
And don't stop writing to me
yet. I am quite as anxious to
come home as you are to have
me, and yet I am in just
as much suspense.
How funny it seems to be
where there are people- men
women and children- to sleep
in a bed! Am getting the crock
marks and the burns off my
fingers already.
The elections passed off to suit
me and my friends here very
much. 
Got Sayrs letter yesterday. Mr.
Cushman told me that he had
saved $100.00 but had been obliged
to use it; he will deposit so
much before my return from
below, in some bank.
I love you and Dete and all the rest
as ever-
Simeon Whiteley.

Century City 

                                                                                             Sept. 13.  1863

My Dear Wife
Arrived here yesterday en route for Conejos via Denver.
Have bid goodbye to the Middle Park for this year.  Left the North Park last 
Tuesday morning.  Nicolay is still with me.  We have had a glorious time.
We leave Denver on the 20th - so I shall have plenty time to fix up my accounts and
write you - if the weather down there is endurable, but even here - 3000 feet
above there, it is hot as

tophet with a little "t".
I have not felt quite so well for a few days past - and
had fears of a return of an old complaint but am all right today.
It seems odd enough to get back to civilization.
My "tent and things" met me 12 miles this ride "the springs."  Your picture
and Dele's looked good enough to kiss.
I have got some bags for unclear nice ones.
In great haste
your
Simeon Whiteley
Had a good visit with Lymon Dutton yesterday.

Denver, Sept. 23     1863

My Darling Wife:  This morning I sent you a telegraphic message addressed to father.  "Have Jane
"and Delia prepare to come.  Have mailed ample "funds."  Unexpected as this would be to you, it
was hardly more so than to me; for it was only this morning that an arrangement was concluded
which gives me editorial control of the now leading newspaper of Colorado,
and a salary for such time as I can devote to it of $1000 00 per ann.
As I shall after my return from Conejos have an uninterrupted stretch of eight months at
least, (in which period Colorado will likely pass from a Territorial condition) you will
see that as against paying my own expenses home, there could be no choice.
To be sure I had some intimation of this long ago, but twice negotiations had been
broken off:- now there is no escape and my pay is guaranteed.  This much of

I send you a draft upon Gov. Evans agent in Chicago for $100 00.  Upon no
consideration must you expend more than $375 00 before coming here.  Should Judge
Jones send you $90 00 you will bring that along too, as I do not consider it mine quite.
You will probably have to pay half stage fare for Delia.  As the nights will be
cold, you want a good supply of shawls &c - A good coarse blanket like mine
would be good for your feet.  By all means bring a good pillow.  Such things don't count as baggage.
I will have a good place for us to stay until your baggage comes along after you.  
Of course you can get along here for two or three weeks without much extra.  All over 25lbs which you
bring in the coach, will cost you 40 to 50c per lb.
I will write you again tomorrow about shipping heavy and bulky things.
I  leave Wednesday for below.

explanation is due to father; and yet I don't care about it going any further:
or coming back here.  I am afraid Mary will be disappointed, as it may break up her school operations.
I am disappointed in a measure, but not wholly.  I had hoped to have entertained many of our folks by 
recitals of experience, most of which has been enjoyed the more by the thought of what fun 
it would be to sit around the fireside and tell of this and that adventure.
But darling, it looks now as if our separation was nearly at an end.
I shall try to get a house that we may once more have a hearthstone
of our own.  It of course will, be a very small one and homely, but Home;
and when I think of it, I can hardly hold in.  We shall probably have to
move about somewhat, but who cares for that.  You shall go along.

you had best bring your bedding, and perhaps buy more; though you
may remember "they say," there is but little severe weather in Denver.
We shall have but little company.  No one expects to invite company to
stay all night here.  But I should like you to bring a good set of dishes -
a nice castor - a doz. silver forks; Knives and spoons enough to match,
table cloths, napkins, and some red or scarlet goods to cover pine lounge stools &c.
You have a looking glass good enough.  Bring but very
few books.  Leave the big Bible, magazines &c.
I haven't yet made up my mind to live in this country.
I want Jones to make me a suit of clothes good enough for church, but no
black or plain cloth about them.  Let the limit for the suit be $36 or $38.

I will write again tomorrow, but except directions for shipping goods,
I think of nothing more.  I haven't time to write compliments or anything else - am greatly hurried.
Have stopped my packing to go East.
You will be here to the "tin wedding."
Goodbye darling.  Be sure and bring Dele.  You will not have a 
very rough time - and we will be home again in season to have her
go to school.
As ever
Your affectionate husband
Simeon Whiteley.

If he hasn't got what you think will suit - write to A.D Fitsworth Chicago
and let the limit be $40 00.  The same would be $90 00 here, 
(Mr. J has my measure.)  Bring your "silver" in a little wicker "silver basket with you.
The money you have already.
I take it will buy you the silk dress you spoke of.
If when you get to Atchison the coach should be full, better wait a day or even
two.  If not more than five inside, you will not have a very hard time of it.
I am going to write to a gentleman today to bring you with him; if he has not already started.
His name is Bartlett.  A good man considering he has been three or four years here.
Don't mention my business arrangement to him and don't be very communicative generally.
It is suspected he has gone to marry a lady at Fon du Lac.
I expect to be back in three weeks from below.
Keep cool as you can.  Don't think the journey over on the fourth or fifth day on
the plains - the sixth is a very long day.

buffalo on Reservation.  Capt. Dusold dont get
tried working for the Indians - when bad white
men come around, he drove them off.
Wants the great father to keep him here.

Judge Starr?- sworn.
Attorneys for protestants declined to
examine this witness at present: for the reason that
he was required to testify before the Senate committee
Peter Cunningham?- sworn.
says         The first place I came to, was Morey
lenies? house. He was standing by the yard fence.
Two young men came to him, those men told
him, that armed men have come to the precinct
directly he went himself to the precinct- 
he stoped in about ten steps from the crowd
at the polls, there he saw these armed men
with double barrelled shot guns and pistols.
I then started back, and went back to Morey
Criers? house; I did not go into the house, but went
into the yard, and met Blue Baldridges son.
I asked Baldridge, if these men were appointed
by the Sheriff to come there, and he answered
not, they were there without  any orders from
the Sheriff at all- then there was several of the
armed party, about that time passed between
the house and the lot fence- they passed the 
house a little ways, and came to a man by
the name of Elmer Fox, and when they came
back, they got a man by the name of Bull??y 
who was near to me, and took both down to the
polls. Blue Baldridges Son, then told me that the
armed men wanted these two men to vote their

ticket, and that was the reason they took them off.
The armed men were Downings? men. I told Blue
Baldridges Son, that these men were dangerous the
way they acted. Baldridge spoke and said, Yes!
they were, and from that I went home without
voting.

  Quest: What time of the day did this take

place.

  Ans. About nine o clock in the morning

I went home about 10 or 11 o clock.

 Quest: Do you remember the names of

these armed men?

  Ans:  One was Bill Hold, John Grease

or Sanders, and one by the name of Bob.

  Quest: Did they have their guns in a 

threatening position?

 Ans. Yes, that was the reason I did not

stay longer than I did.

  Quest. What was the threatening position
     In this way (witness shows that

the guns were held at the hip in the military
position of  a charge, with the muzzle pointed
down.

Judge Falkner- Sworn.
Says     I went to the Court House, the day after
the election where the Superintendants of election
had assembled. I heard them talking in the
house, and it seemed that they were about to 
disagree upon some subject or other, and I then
went in to the house. I heard Thomas Ross, one
of the clerks, tell in English, that Mr. Columbus
Benge, wanted his name scratched off the Lees
Creek precinct rolls- that he was compelled
to put it on contrary to his will, or words
to that effect. William Patton, remarked
"nare a time," would he take it off, if he
(Benge) wanted to take it off, he could take
it off his self. And Mr. Ross was looking
for his (Benges) name, and showing it to him.
When I went out, I did not see him scratch
it out himself. Some little time after, one of
the Judges or clerks, came to me, and asked
me, if it would not be well to write to the
Chief, why they had failed to give certificates
to any of the candidates I told them it was
some thing new to me, but I thought it
was likely to be best. When William Patton,
wrote out some thing that I heard him read,
but I do not know who signed it. He said 
he would put it in with the returns and
he did. The papers that he wrote, said in

words to this effect." What he regretted was
they had failed to issue certificates of election
to any of the candidates whatever, on the grounds,
that it was claimed by some, that the election
on Lees Creek was illegal. That is all that
I know of the subject

 Quest: Did you as District Judge, appoint and

qualify the superintendants and clerks of election
in the manners required by the law?

 Ans. I did. But I was told that one

of clerks did not attend, but I did not qualify
him, I only wrote to him

 Quest: I appointing the superintendants

of election, did you appoint them, so that the opposing
candidates, would have representation?

 Ans: I did.
   Did you qualify the clerk, that was

appointed at Lees Creek precinct in place of
the one that was absent?

  Ans. No sir

Sam Benge, Sworn

says

 I was there at the Court House the next day

after the election when they brough the papers on
rolls there of Lees Creek precinct, they were
not sealed. I think John Gunter brought the
rolls to the Court house, when the rolls were
brought to the Court House we would not 
accept of them because they were not sealed.
John Gunter was the clerk at the Lees Creek
precinct, and I asked Gunter if he was 
appointed clerk, by the Judges, and he said he
was not: He said that Albert Johnson authorized
him to be clerk, or told him to clerk, I asked
Gunter, if he was not a candidate for Sheriff
in that district? Gunter said he was, I then
told Gunter, that he had no right to act
as clerk, being that he was a candidate for
office. From that they came to a conclusion
that they could not come to an understanding
what they were to do. And from that
issued no certificates of election.

   What was the cause of those returns

not being sealed, that was brought to the Court
house, the next day?

  Ans I do not know the reason, but 

I heard it?

  Quest: Who did you hear it from?

Ans. One of the Superintendants of election

at that precinct told me.

     When I got to the Court house I asked

Columbus Benge, if he had the returns from
Lees Creek precinct. Benge said he did not
have them, but, that John Gunter, had run
away with them, Benge said it was mighty
dangerous at that precinct. John Lee came
very near- shooting him, but the pistol snaped,
Benge told me that he did not want to
sign the rolls, but he was compelled to
sign them through fear, but he signed
them because he was afraid of those men.
The next day when they met at the  Court
house in Sequoyah District, Columbus Benge
took his name of the Rolls or returns of
Lees Creek precinct. When Columbus Benge
took his name off the returns, he told them
when he signed the roll he was afraid
but now he was not afraid.

An Act providing for breadstuffs
for the Cherokee people
Approved Nov. 19 1874
Whereas, it appears from numerous petitions, signed by many citizens from various parts of this nation,
that because of the protracted drouth that prevailed throughout this country during the past
spring and summer, That there is and will be great scarcity of breadstuffs
among the people, and that as a consequence thereof there will be much
suffering among the people if left alone to their own limited resources,
until the crops of the next summer shall have matured.  And whereas,
The people have petitioned for aid in obtaining breadstuffs sufficient
to relieve them until their crops of the next season shall have matured
Therefore, 

               Be it enacted by the National Council,

That the Cherokee delegation about to proceed to
The seal of government of the

United States at Washington, be and
they are hereby instructed and directed, to negotiate with the proper 
authorities of the United States, on the
most reasonable terms, a loan of 
Five hundred Thousand dollars ($500.000)
to be refunded out of the proceeds of the Cherokee lands lying west of the
Arkansas river and South of Kansas when realized, and the said funds
shall be and they are hereby appropriated to be paid to the whole Cherokee
people "per capita", in the manner herein after prescribed to enable them to
purchase breadstuffs.
Be it further enacted, That for
The purpose of carrying out the provisions of this act, that the Principal
Chief, by and with the advise of the Executive Council. be and he is hereby
authorized at his earliest convenience, in the manner most feasible and 
economical, to have correct roles taken of the whole Cherokee people
within the limits of the Cherokee nation
and to turn over the same when compelled, certified to by him, to
the treasurer of the Cherokee nation

and it shall Therefore be the duty of the said Treasurer to fill the said roles
in his office, and as soon thereafter as he may be advised by any proper authority
that the said funds have been realized by the Cherokee authorities,
he shall make requisition for the same upon the proper authority of the
United States, on securing said funds
it shall be the duty of said treasurer to 
pay the same out per capita, to the
whole Cherokee people according to 
the said census roles.  Tho making said payments the 
Treasurer is hereby directed to pay the funds in person, to all adult
persons entitled to the same, and to
parents, guardians and heads of families
representing minors and disabled persons, and no other person or persons
whomever.  A receipt we shall be kept
by the Treasurer, showing the payments made
and to whom, and which shall be reported to the National Council next 
following said payment.
Be it further Enacted, that the Principal Chief be and he is hereby
authorized to draw warrants payable out of any funds belonging to the

general fund, and not otherwise appropriated, to pay the expenses of taking
The census rolls herein provided per
William Roper
Principal Chief

Sir:  You have been designated by the President, to perform the duties of the Office of U.S
Indian Inspector, vice D. Bevier, suspended.
If you accept the trust, please file in this Office the required Oath, a blank form of which is herewith transmitted.
Upon the receipt here of the Oath, your commission,
with a letter of entrustment, will be forwarded to you.
The compensation of the Office is at the rate of $3000 per annum, with an allowance of necessary
travelling expenses, not exceeding ten cents per mile.
Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant,
N.R Lum
Acting Commissioner

May 14th, 1875

Errin C Watkins, Esqur,
U.S Indian Inspector,
Rockford, Michigan.
Sir:   
This office is in receipt of your letter dated the 1st instant, accepting the appointment
of U.S Indian Inspector, vice D. Bevier, suspended;
and, enclosing your Oath of Office.
Herewith I transmit your commission, dated the 31st March, last, together with a printed copy of the
Act of Congress, approved February 14th, 1874,
providing for the appointment of Indian Inspector.
The provisions of the 6th section of the act referred
to, are sufficiently explicit to acquaint you, in a 
general way, with the powers and duties of your office;
which, however, may be supplemented by the 
following remarks:-  The office to which you are
appointed, was created for the purpose of promoting
greater efficiency in the efforts now being made by
the Government, to bring all Indians in the United States
under the power and influence of civilization.

2
One of the first requisites for successful labor to this end, is believed to be the securing of proper
persons to represent the Government in the work, as Agents and Agency Employees.  The Agent needs
to be a man of unflinching integrity, cool, firm, wise and kind; who believes in the feasibility of
Indian civilization and has entered upon his office with an earnest purpose of securing its accomplishment,
as far and as rapidly as possible, among his wards.
The Employed should be persons of good moral character,
with a fair knowledge of the trade, or branch of work,
to which they are assigned; and in all cases they
should be persons whose example is a worthy one for ignorant people to follow - and like the Agent.
thoroughly committed, in sympathy and faith, to the work of civilization.  Schools for Indians are
regarded as the great lever for their uplifting.
The tendency, however, in all such schools is toward the routine of forms under which little actual
good is accomplished.  This, in all cases, it should be the endeavor of the Inspector to prevent or
have corrected.
The main usefulness of your office, in addition to the performance of the duties prescribed by the law,

3
above noticed, relative to the Examination of accounts, &c,
will be found in your ability to impress both Agents
and Employees with a sense of their responsibility, and
to give them such advice and information as will
promote their greater efficiency and usefulness;
also, to furnish such information for use in this Office,
as will lead to any changes that may be desirable for
procuring the proper service.
The present efforts toward civilization are based
on the theory that barbarous men will really improve
their condition only in proportion as they can be
induced to accept individual responsibility, and
to taken upon themselves some form of labor.  The
Agent, therefore, should be instructed and advised
in all methods tending to individually and industry,
in the tribes under his care.
A tendency is found to have been prevalent
among the Agents, to keep up an establishment
with a considerable force of Employers at no small
expense to the Government, out of which comes little
of actual benefit to the Indians.  Except that
which is produced by observation of a well ordered
Establishment kept on their reservation.  Instead of this,
the main labor of the Agent, and that of the Employers,

4
should be expended on the farms and the improvements of the Indians.  In this correction, the attention
of the Agent and his Employer should be constantly directed to the importance of so instructing of certain
number of Indians, apprentices on his reservation, that they may be prepared as soon as possible to
conduct their mechanical and agricultural affairs without the intervention of white labor; and this should
be insisted upon, notwithstanding the general reluctance among Indians to keep steadily at any trade or business.
By the annual appropriation for each Agency, a certain amount of money is made available; the
proper use of which money, is necessarily left largely to the discretion of the Agent.  Great che should be
exercised by the Inspector, to ascertain not only whether such moneys are honestly disbursed; but,
also, whether the best use is being made of them in employment of service and the purchase of
material, and in other disbursements.
In order to approach an Agency intelligently, and be able to answer many inquiries, which will
naturally be made, both by the Agent and the Indians,
the Inspector should thoroughly inform himself concerning all treaties made by the United States with the Indians,

5
and the appropriations for the year, made by Congress in accordance with these treaties, or otherwise.
In all interviews with the Indians, care should be exercised not to pledge the government
in any way, unless specially authorized to to do, nor to make statements in any such form, as to
incur the liability of their being misconstrued into promises.
In any recommendation which you may find it proper to make to the office, relative to
disbursements, reference should constantly be had to funds which you may know to be available,
or otherwise, for such purposes; and a distraction should be made, between a recommendation of
a use of funds already available, and a recommendation for steps to be taken to procure future appropriations,
which may be made available for the desired purpose:
And all recommendations involving an expenditure of funds, should be accompanied by an estimate
f the cost of the same:
While it is quite important that you give a full hearing to all proper criticisms or complaints
against any Agent, by any party, and invite a full and fair presentation of the same, you should also

6
be aware, that any Agent is liable to become the victim of dislike and malice, on the part of those whom he may
have offended by a conscientious discharge of duty.
In all such investigations, a full statement of the case should be made, with the definite conclusions
reached and the recommendations made by the Inspector.
It is believed that you will be able by observations made at the several Agencies, as
they pass under your inspection, to obtain such facts as will enable you to carry valuable suggestions
from one Agency to another, and also to make such recommendations to this Bureau, as will
largely increase the efficiency of its administration.
In order that the necessary steps may be taken to correct any abuse or error; or meet any 
emergency found to exist at any point, your reports on all matters herein referred to, should be made
immediately after the examination of each Agency;
and in order to facilitate communication of information,
often required to be sent by telegram, you will make weekly reports,
according to the blanks which will be forwarded to you, of your post office and telegraphic
address.  Such care should be taken in making these reports, as to enable the Office at any times to

7
communicate readily with you.
Such other instructions, as may be found
proper and necessary, for the good of the service,
will be given you as occasion may require.
Your salary will be at the rate of three
thousand dollars per annum, to commence with
the date of the filing of your Oath in this Office,
the 6th instant; and you will be allowed your travelling
expenses, not to exceed ten cents per mile, while
actually engaged in the discharge of official duty.
Very respectfully,
your obedient servant,
Edw Phillips
Commissioner

2.  There is a P.O at Qualla Town.  (the agency)
why is official mail stopped at Webster 2.  The latter
place being 15 miles from Qualla Town.
3.  At Qualla Town - find Dr. J.K Welch, who can
give you a great deal of information in connection
with the lands comprised within the limits of the
Qualla Boundary.  He is also thoroughly posted
as to Indian matters in that country.  I regard him
a safe man to talk with.  He is a magistrate and
what is not always the case he is an intelligent one.
4.  Loyd R. Welch - the lately elected chief of the
Eastern Band of Cherokees, is a half breed, quite
intelligent and a man whose story should be
heard.   He asserts knowledge of misuse of public
funds - as for instance, buying a pair of oxen for
use at a saw mill and charging the cost to sick and
indigent Indians - loaning by check one hundred dollars
of public funds, to one Mr. Spake of Webster. N.C 
paying one dollar each for corn to feed Indians,

in a country where the article could be had in any quantity for fifty cents in trade.
Feeding these Indians against the protest of
- and Loyd Welch and others who
assert that this feeding lost to the Indians not
less than twenty-five hundred bushels of corn
growing in the fields - because being fed by the Agent
they neglected their crops.
Loyd Welch has also an opinion to offer in regard 
to schools - also in regard to late election for
chief - and many other matters - notably James Taylor's
claim to represent the Eastern Cherokees as delegate
in Washington & elsewhere - Welch denies Taylor is
the accredited agent of the Eastern Cherokees.
5.  Mr. E. Shuder - Banker at Asherville and Dr. D.F Sunnery
at the Bank Hotel will be able to give you
some information regarding the safe keeping of an
envelope from Agent McCarthy said to contain $700. 00.
6.  Mr. Albert Sunnery of Asheville was named
by me to the office - as a suitable person to be selected
to hold the office of Trustee in connection
with the lands recently recovered to the Eastern
Band of Cherokees, in N.C - He is a merchant
doing business opposite the Bank Hotel and I 
believe is an honest capable man and free from
connections with any of the various little rings
in that vicinity.
7.  In case you desire an interview with Loyd R.
Welch - his address is - Care of Dr. J. K Welch,
Qualla Town - N.C, via Webster. Jackson co.

7th.  The acts of the council of October 6th ultimo
were placed in the hands of Official Agent McCarthy
Oct. 23rd for transmission to the Dept
and at this date (Nov. 11th) they are not in
the Dept.  I believe these acts are purposely
withheld by McCarthy to give Taylor, who is
here in Washington, an opportunity to have the
election set aside and a new one ordered.
and that when McCarthy learns that this is
done that he will then forward the act of council.
McCarthy and Taylor work together in
this thing - These two had a meeting
while I was at Qualla Oct 21st or 22d last, but neither of
them would vie me an inkling of their plans - I
learned however that Taylor was there to head off
the Acts so that he Taylor could get here and have
the election of Welch set aside - which he has
succeeded in doing so far as the Indian Office is
concerned - They cannot manage Loyd Welch so they have no use for him.
8.  The purchase of school books in an out of the way 
place like Ashville has a fishy look about it.  Ask McCarthy-
I am not alone in holding an unfavorable
opinion of McCarthy and Taylor - Professor Stevenson
of Hayden's U.S Geological Survey, who was
one of my colleagues, was of opinion that McCarthy is
a religious fraud, and that both he and Taylor are on the
dead made - In all of which I concur.

the report of my inspection of the Agency.

  The appropriations, since Maj [[name}] has been

the title here, have been expended ni legal, economical

 The burning of the Agency buildings tractor?

and seem to have the idea, that the Great Farther

 In this course, they are encouraged by a few

unclear and from the world, without loss.

 The Agent here, Sr B. Sperry, has earlier

    The Indians make bitter complaints

they are very anxious
for a new agent, and do not hesitate to charge

and half breds. Unfortunately Maj Sperry has

6


mosphere of unpopularity, which to a

better for the service, to put a new man, in his
