Sir:

 I have the honor to submit the

following report of my inspection of the
Neah Bay Agency, and investigation of
the Administration of Agent C. A. name
which resulted in his suspension,
as telegraphed you, this P. M.

 Early on the morning of the 16th inst. I

left Seattle by Steamer for Port Townsend
arriving there, before noon the same day.

 At the latter place, through the courtesy 

of Capt. name (who obtained authority
from the Treasury Dept) I was taken on
board the Revenue Cutter, and conveyed to
Neah bay, reaching there, the following day,
at an early hour.

 The reservation, presents a forbidding

appearance,- being mountainous and heavily
timbered to the waters unclear except the few
acres that have been cleared adjacent

2


to the Indian Village at the upper end
of the bay. But very little land has been
cultivated. In the immediate vicinity of
the employes houses, and the old school house,
there is a small field of unclear unclear, 
containing perhaps two or three acre. This and a 
couple of small gardens, attached to the
residences of two of the employes
comprizes the land under cultivation at this
point. What is called the Agency farm,
lags to the South, back of unclear unclear, and as
the farmer states in his affidavit,
transmitted herewith,- is composed of four or
five acres of ploughed land. A few 
potatoes, and other vegetables are growing on it, 
according to the Statements of the employes.

 This is all the farming there is done on the

reservation. The Indians are not
cultivating any land at all. I was not able to
reach the place called name farm, on account
of high water. but I learn that something
like a thousand acres of tide lands

3


can be reclaimed in this vicinity with a
small onlay for unclear, and think it
would be money well expended.

  No where in the United States, have I found

the Indians so filthy, and so poorly clothed
as at Neah Bay. They are principally 
conspicuous for their lack of clothing. I
saw several adult males about the
village, and in the unclear sentence entirely
naked. And as a rule, the men wear nothing
but a shirt, with a blanket thrown over
the shoulder, which leaves the naked legs 
revealed. The women, are better dressed
than the men, at least their nakedness is
covered. The lack of dress, on the part of the
men, is partly due to their being in the water
so much: as their only occupation is fishing.
They live in a long row of board houses
along the beach, most of which, adjoin.

The houses are large in size,- frequently being

20 * 40 feet, and in each, live from two to five 
families,- all in one room.

4


These are unclear with smoke and
weather stained, leaky and reeking with
filth. The Indians live to a great extent on
fish, and the decaying remnants of the many
varieties of fish eaten, both inside the
houses, and outside, emit a stench that is
most offensive, and must be very unhealthy.

 Living together, in this filthy promiscuous

manner, it is not surprizing that
they have but little chastity, and less modesty.
I do not unclear that the main portion
of them are any more virtuous, or civilized
than when the first Government Agent
went amongst them.  From what I learn
of the work of former Agents, and see of the
present one, I am led to believe that the
Government, has been peculiarly unfortunate
in its selections for this Agency.

  The Agent himself, lives some two

miles away from the Indians, in the house
formerly owned by Mr. Webster, situate on
a high rocky point, to the North, which house

5


and the other buildings, belonging to the property
together with a trail of land, of no possible
value to the Indians, were added to the 
reservation by Executive order, a few years ago.

  There is a costly, and substantial school

building, near the Indian village, now
unused, except for service, occasionally, on
the Sabbath day, neglected, and rapidly going
to decay: but the present Agent did not like
the location, and has erected another building
adjoining the house, in which he lives; for a 
school house. Under the circumstances, I 
think the money, put into the new school
building was very poorly expended.

  The school, however, seems to be rather

successful. There are about 40 children, now
in it, most of whom are less that ten year
old, who show commendable progress.

 It is the only redeeming work in Agent

name administration. It has absorbed
nearly the entire appropriation, as shown by the
accounts, and nearly all that is done by em

6


ployers is in connection with the school.
Mr. Smith stands on the rolls as Blacksmith
but he does no work, in the shop, and is not a 
practical blacksmith, as will be seen by
his affidavit, herewith transmitted. He is 
a sort of man-of-all-work, about the Agents
house, and the school.

 The second day, I was there, the

Indians assembled in the school house at the village
and gave them an opportunity
to talk. Agent name of Gen. Howards staff,
and four officers from the Revenue Cutter.

  The Indians all coincided in calling

Mr. name the worst Agent they have ever had. This is not unclear sentence
They charged him with selling the Govt.
supplies and goods furnished for the Indians,
and several of them enumerated articles that
they had bought, and paid money for, to the
Agent. They claimed that the cattle on the
reservation, were being killed off and sold for
beef by Agent name. In several instances,
Indians stated, that their own private

7

cattle, had been taken away from them by
him, and thus disposed of. They stated that he
was in the habit of imposing fines, for slight
offenses, which were paid in money by the 
Indians, and asked, with much force, what he
did with the money.

   A brief summary of what was said in

this public talk, by the Indians, as taken
down by Capt. Wilkinson, is enclosed here-
with.

   I examined nearly all the employes,

the trader, and former trader, under oath,
and took down the substance of their statements
in the nature of affidavits, which I enclose
with this report, and desire to have examined
in connection with it.

 I scrutinized Agent name books,

and accounts very closely, and from these 
various sources-viz-the statements of the
Indians, the affidavits enclosed, and from
the records in his office. I am led to believe
that he has signally failed to carry out

8

the policy of the Government, toward the
Indians, in this. that in violation of law,
he has sold supplies and goods of various
kinds, to both white men and Indians, for 
purposes of personal gain.

   That he has sold a portion of the supplies

and goods furnished by the Govt. for the Indians,
to both white men and Indians, and has not
accounted for the proceeds.

  That he has sold some of the cattle, belonging to the

Govt. and the Indians, in they way of beef, and has
not accounted for the money received.

  That he has in some instances taken

vouchers for larger sums than was actually
paid, as in the case of A. W. Smith- teacher
and Jim (Indian) cook.

  That he has carried members of his

family on the roll of employes, while they
did little or no work in that capacity.,
and were at the same time, at work for other
parties, and receiving pay for the scam. As in 
the case of Bilos name, his son who

9


was carried on the rolls, as an employe
for about one year, while he was
employed by Mr. Sandes- the trader- as a 
clerk in his store, at a salary of $1000.00 a year.

   Also J. M. name- another son

who was carried on the roll of employes
for two years, ending about the 1st of
July last, while he was also a clerk for
Mr. Sandes, the trader, at a salary of
$1000.00 a year. A portion of this time, he
stood on the roll of employes as black-
smith and drew $900.00 a year salary from
the Govt. He does not claim to be a black-
smith, and did little, if any work, in that
capacity. He is now employed by Mr.
Gallick the present trader, at a salary of
$100.00 a month, and stands on the roll of
employes (as given me by Agent name
on my arrival) for the present quarter, as
clerk, at a salary of $500, a year.

 That Agent name solicited aid

for his Indians from the benevolent people

10

of Portland, and other places, and received a 
quantity of 2nd hand clothing, which
was shipped to him, - (the Government paying
the freight on the scam, as his accounts show)
for distribution among the Indians at
Neah Bay, and that unclear a part of this
charitable contribution, was sold to the
Indians, for money, and the scam converted
to his own use.

  His administration has been a disgrace

to the public service, and a shame to the
Christian church, in which he stands as a 
minister.

  For the reasons above given, Mr. name

was suspended by written order from
me, of this date, and Capt George D. Will, a
retired Army officer, living at Seattle W. T.
was designated to perform the duties of
his office- temporarily- subject to the
approval of the Indian Office. Copies of the order
of suspension and the order designating Capt. Will
are enclosed herewith.

                                                                                                              October 26th 1877

General E.C Watkins
N.J Indian Inspector
Palace Hotel San Francisco Cal
Dear Sir
I met a man today by the name of H. Rixley who lives near Silver City Idaho.
He states that a short time ago he was in company with a man by the name
of Turner who said that he Turner was a Special Indian Agent.
Wm Riley states that he heard Turner say to some men who were in company
with him that he intended to "burst - up" the Duck Valley reservation
stating that it was too cold to raise anything in that vicinity that he should lay the 
matter before congress and have the reservation discontinued.  I do not know who W Turner is
I cannot find his name in the Annual Reports.  I do however know that his statements are false
in regard to Duck Valley.  I have seen as fine wheat, barley, and oats growing in Duck Valley

2
As ever green in any country Mr. Levi Harris has raised grain and vegetables in that valley
for the past 4 years.  He tells me that he has raised 45 bushels of wheat to the acre without
any trouble.  I saw as fine potatoes which grew in Duck Valley as I ever saw.  The Indians
themselves have selected them - locality for a reservation and have urged upon
me for several years past to do all in my power to have a reservation set apart for them in 
Duck Valley.  After a careful inspection of the country I consider it a suitable place for a home for
the Shoohorses.  I am very sorry that the report that the reservation was sure to be (as stated by)
Mr. Turner "bursted up" -  It will cause the Indians to be discouraged and have no confidence in me,
the Government - or anybody else I have promised them that - that country should be and even was
reserved for them.  My reasons for doing this was the instruction embodied in the Official letter from
the Honorable Commissioner of Indian Affairs inclosing executive order dated April 16th 1877 which
I sent to you I do note fear that Mr. Turner

3
can succeed in me doing what I have done this summer without the matter being investigated at
least, The circulation of such reports has a bad affect upon the Indians.  You are aware
what kind of people Indians are to deal with.
I do sincerely hope that you will be able to visit to location in question on your return to Washington.
It is the only place in Nevada unclaimed suitable for a home for the Shoohones.  There are some
stuck men in Idaho and Oregon who are anxious to have Duck Valley for a Summer range for their
stock and are willing to pay something to keep the Indians out of their locality.  I am reliably informed
that this is the reason Duck Valley is too frosty for an Indian reservation.  Mr.  Turner pretends to have
great influence and told the stuck men who were with him at the time referred to by Rixley that he
Turner should have the whole thing bursted up during this the extra session of Congress I shall
write to Senator Jones and the Representative (unclear) in regard to the matter and state the truth of the

4
cast & I am sorry the report has been circulated because the delay that has occurred will lead the
Indians to believe that there is something wrong.
Capt. Sam and several other Indians have gone to Duck Valley with their families and are waiting
for me to come with supplies so they can go to work.
Winter is fast approaching and the Indians are very uneasy for fear we cannot move the bridge this fall
and make other preparations for farming, and in the face of these disadvantages the report being 
circulated that the whole thing is to be bursted up is not very encouraging for the Indians.
I told them that I expected to have their annuity goods and other supplies at cornucopia by the middle of
the fall (October) but cannot get them there I don't believe, until near the first of December.
General, I would like very much to hear from you as soon as it is convenient to write.
Nothing has been done in regard to my appointment as special Agt
that I am aware of.  With kindest regards to yourself and best wishes for your success.
I have the honor to be your sincere friend and obed servant.
Levi A Green

Col E. C Watkins
U.S Ind Inspector
When visiting Pawnee Agency please take samples off Flour, Sugar & Coffee and forward to this office.  State definitely
what quantity each sample represents, the contractors and inspectors names, and the dates of deliveries.
If there are different qualities of each of these articles, forward samples of each quality.  Samples of about a half pound of each,
in tin cans, tied so that they may be opened by postmaster, and not sealed, can be sent through the mail, prepaid.
Certificates or affiliates of Agent and employees, would be well, if the samples are of such quality as to warrant a

claim or deduction from contracted account.
The Agent of Pawnees, in his monthly report, does not mention the occurrences which have
taken place at his agency during the last month.  If you call for a copy of his report, you will find
that it does not inform the office of matters of vital interest, which should have been communicated.
You may find it necessary to go to the new Ponca reservation by the route from Mage to Pawnee Agency,
in order to cross the Arkansas River by boat.  Keep composed E. A Wayt informed by Telegraph as
to your movements, and I will arrange to have the payments of money annuities to Indians, made at the
Mage Agency upon your return northward from the Pawnee Agency.
(Written at request of Commsr Hoyt)  Wm M, Leeds

Col E.C Watkins
U.S Indian Inspector
Sir;
While at the Osage Agency you will call a council of those Chiefs, Headmen,
and councilors of the Osage Nation, who are said to have signed a certificate of
certain proceedings, which occurred in a Council held on the 2nd of June 1876, as per the
document herewith.  You will call upon the Agent to produce the Original from which this Copy
was made; and you will make enquiry of the parties whose signatures it purports to bear,
as to the facts alleged and the genuiness of the document.
As it is the policy of the Government

to do away with "Tribal" relations the arrangement under date of June 2 1876, will be discontinued.
As to the payments of Annuities to the Osage Indians, as well as the payments of such Salaries
as you shall find to have been agreed upon by the Osages in Council, as per the
documents herewith, you will witness the same, seeing that each individual receives the full
amount due to him, and for which he signs, in cash; but no payments must be made until
after you shall have first verified through a council the proceedings said to have taken
place on the 2d of June 1876.
Respectfully
E A Hay
Commissioner

Col. E. C. Watkins
U.S Indian Inspector
Washington D.C.
Sir 
You are hereby instructed to proceed to the Quapaw Indian 
Reservation; there to meet, and take charge of a delegation of Ponca Indians,
who will be chosen by their tribe to select Lands in the Indian Territory
for their future occupancy, and exclusive use and benefit.
After selecting such Lands you will proceed to the Pawnee
Indian Agency and inspect the Affairs thereof; thence to the Osage
Agency and inspect its affairs; and also witness the payments of annuities
to the Indians located at said Agency and on the Osage Reservation.
After the completion of the duties above mentioned you will
return northward to the line of the Union Pacific Railway, and
over it and the Central Pacific Railway you will proceed to San
Francisco.  From San Francisco you will proceed to the San Carlos

Agency in Arizona; visiting the Colorado river & Pima and Maricopa Agencies also, and
making a thorough inspection of all of their affairs.  Having finished the inspections
of these Agencies you will proceed to the Southern Apaches, the Mescalero Apache, the Pueblo,
and the Arbequina Agencies.
During your stay in Arizona and New Mexico you will take occasion to visit
any points where information may be obtained that will tend to show the true
condition of the Indians, and of Indian affairs, in those Territories.
Upon the Inspection of the affairs of the various Agencies herein
named, you will forward a report of the condition of each in detail;
and proceeding to the nearest telegraph station will communicate with
this office, and await further orders.
Respectfully
C A Hayes
Commissioner

copy
In the matter of the trespass of the
cattle of H. A. Webster on the Indian
Reservation of Neah Bay.

        Statement.

Webster a former Agent,in going
from this Reservation, left  upon it,
a band of cattle, his personal property,
about sixty head.
After the cattle had remained for
a considerable length of time, the
Commissioner of Indian Affairs, 
authorized C. A. Huntington, the present
Agent, as such agent, and for the benefit
of the Indian service, to make a
contract of pasturage, with Webster,
by which he should pay to Huntington,
as afore said, at the rate of one
dollar per head, per annum, for the
pasturage of the cattle, from the
time they were left upon the 
Reservation. Huntington being led to think
he had Webster's permission, killed
a steer, from this band, and appropriated
it to the use of the Indians, giving
Webster credit on the pasturage account
Webster refused his consent, and
refused to make payment for the
pasturage, except by offsetting certain

2.

alleged claims he had against the
Government, that upon presentation
had been rejected. Huntington informed
the Indian Department of Webster's 
conduct & requested instructions.
He was directed to seize the cattle,
to slaughter and make such other
use of them as he deemed, for the
interest of the Indian service, thus 
satisfying the demand for pasturage.
and relieving himself, from
the annoyance, the cattle were causing,
upon the Reservation. Huntington
seized the cattle, Milked some
of the cows and kept control of the
band. Webster sued Huntington
in two suits for trespasses, respecting
the cattle, for killing, milking and
the like. Huntington defended, by
admitting the killing of a steer and 
his acts under the instructions of
the Indian Department.
These defenses were ruled untenable
for the reason the Indian Department
could not lawfully direct Huntington
to appropriated Websters property.
But the Jury were informed Huntington's 
remedy was a seizing and selling
the cattle for damage feasant.

3.

The cattle are still upon this Reservation,
greatly to Huntington's annoyance
as Agent. He wishes to proceed to
relieve himself of them.

 So the present time, the unclear of

W. unclear have held the Indian Reservations 
to be placed under the exclusive
jurisdiction of U. S. Hence the
Territorial laws do not extend over 
them, and the lien law for pasturage
would not operate there.

 Whether the common law lien in

such case obtains, as a part of the
federal system of laws, I very much
doubt.      If a lien were given
there being no remedy provide, 
then of course the rule of the
common law would govern.
I think all possessory right to the
Reservation was by the government
ceded to the Indians, I think the
depasturing an injury to the possession
and not to the realty. That the Indians
and not the government, are the
parties damaged. That the
Indian Department could not lease
or give this Reservation to pasturage.

  That the real parties in interest

are the Indians and that if recovery

4.

is had, they or some one representing
them, would have to institute the
suit.    If suit is brought, I
incline to think it would be for
the reasonable worth of the
pasturage, to be shown on the trial.
It being on a remote and inaccessible
part of the public domain, the value
might be reduced to a mere 
nominal sum.

  In view of the facts, and what I

am at present inclined to think
the law to be, I inclined to advise,
that Webster be notified to remove 
his cattle as he doubtless, before this
has been, and that he be sued for the
penalty of taking cattle into the
Indian Country, without conscent
of the Indian tribe, as provided in
Dec, 21 17 for the Revised Statutes, and
the suit repeated for every continuation
of the trespass. In this way I think
he can soon be forced to remove
the cattle.         I regard this a
cumulative remedy. ( but the suit
for pasturage, on part of the Indian
being troublesome, on account of
the number interested, and the place
of seizing being of doubtful legality

5.

Still I think, if vigorously invoked
it will effect all that is required
and, enable the Indian Agent to
avoid all complications- growing
out of the matter.

                Very respectfully
                 J. B. Allen, U. S. Atty.
                         for W. unclear

To C. A. Huntington

Indian Agent,

to be forwarded to the
Commissioner of Indian Affrs.

Extract

" Because he (Webster) could not use me
in his scheme to sell those cattle to the
Govt. at an exorbitant price, he resolved to
destroy me. I have been fully advised of
his intentions for a year. He has not
disguised them to his friends nor mine.
For a year past he has been gathering
items of the Indians and others (Swan 
acting as his instrument) with which
to predjudice the inspector and get me
removed. When the inspector came he hell
first into Captain Hills hands, then into
Websters hands, who sent him down in
the Company of Swan to act as guide
and interpretor. He came charged to the
muzzle with suspicion and predjudice.
The result is known. I wont reflect on the
inspectors motives. I know he was predjudiced
and I saw in the outset that if he could
find any pretext for my suspension, that
apologies or explanations would avail
me nothing and I attempted none. In
fact no fair opportunity was given me.
His clerk privately advised me in the
start what to expect. Said he, they
are after you. He referred to a certain
letter which I wrote some years ago

which exposed the frauds of the military
then in the Indian since. By reason of
which exposure they were all legislated
out. Capt. Hill then agent at Tulalip
court by the board with the rest of them.
The inspectors clerk hinted enough to
me to make me know that the old
fight was renewed and that I was to
be victimized. When I came to talk with
the Inspector himself this was more
manifest, for he told me that he and Hill were old
friends from the same state and that
he had very high respect for him. And 
when Hill finally came to relieve
me leaving his office as treasurer
of King County to take my place, then
everything was clear to me. Hill had
thirsted for revenge for 7 years. Webster
wanted him at Neah Bay because
he can use him. He wanted me
away because he can't use me.
Hill was his supple tool as one of the
appraisers of his property when it was
taken into the reservation to prize it at
$20,000. Webster had tried for years
to sue that property at $5,000 and 
failed to get a purchaser. When he
was agent there he offered it to me

fro $3,000 and offered to resign in my
favor. When it was taken by the Govt.
he proposed an arbitration as he did to
me about the cattle. The Supt. put his
foot in. He chose one De Voor a Methodist
preacher. Webster chose Montgomery a 
personal friend and they chose Hill as
the third man. Montgomery marked $40,000.
De Voor $16,000. Hill $20,000 and on 
this mark they agreed. The cost of
commission and award with all the
incidental expenses amounted to near $30,000.
Webster got his $20,000, but Montgomery
himself told me that it cost Webster

half the money to get it through.

For De Voors share in the fraud he
was deposed by the Methodist Church
and silenced. I believe however that
the conference afterwards accepted his
confession, pardoned and reinstated 
him"

Refer in reply to the following C.                       DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR,

                                                                             OFFICE OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
                                                                               WASHINGTON, March 23, 1878

E. C. Watkins, Esq.
U. S. Indian Inspector
San Carlos agency, Camp Grant, A. L.
Sir:

    Your attention is called to the 

importance of a thorough examination
into the condition of the Agencies in
Arizona and New Mexico, and such
accommodations in regard to their
future management, as you may
deem advisable to make.

   It has been the desire of the office

for several years past, to get the
consent of the Pima Maricopa, and
other Indians in Arizona, to remove
to the Indian Territory but they have

Watkins 2
generally been averse to any change
of this character. The office, however
is in receipt of information of a 
recent date, from the Agent of the
Pima and Maricopa Indians, that
owing to the drouth in Arizona his
Indians are disposed to consent to a
change, and he recommends that
a delegation be permitted to visit
the Indian Territory for the purpose
of making a proper selection of
land, and is also of the opinion
that the Papagoes will consent to
accompany the Pima and Maricopa
Indians, should the removal take
place. There are no funds at the
disposal of the office applicable
to meet the expense of such a visit,
but the office is disposed to ask

Watkins 3
a small appropriation for the purpose
should it be deemed advisable. You
will therefore make such 
recommendation after an investigation of
the condition of the Agency, and the
Indians, as the facts may warrant.

 Numerous complaints have been

made to the office on account of
Indians who have left their 
reservations in Arizona, and are
occupying other lands. This is particularly
the case with some of the Pima and
Maricopa Indians, who, with the
consent of the Agent, and on account
of the want of water to irrigate their
lands, are cultivating lands in what is
known as the Salt River Country. Their
condition and their disposition to join

Watkins 4
their tribe in case of removal should be
ascertained. Complaints have also
been made against the Hualapai
Indians, who are scattered throughout
Mohave County, Arizona and the 
adjacent country, and who seem averse
to being brought upon a reservation.
You will gather such information
in regard to them, and make such
recommendation as time and
circumstances will permit.
The office is also in receipt of
irregularities in the conduct of the
the business of some of the licensed 
traders, at the Agencies, particularly
at San Carlos. The Agent was advised
on the 15th ultimo of the revocation
of the license of the trader, George H
Stevens, at that Agency, and recent

Watkins 5
advices have been received, that said
trader is still pursuing his business,
and that improper persons are
permitted to visit the reservation, greatly
to the Injury and discredit of the
services. You will at this, as well as
at other Agencies, which you may 
visit make a thorough investigation of
the manner in which the traders 
conduct their business, report any
delinquencies that may come under your
observation, or any failures to comply
with the laws, rules and regulations of the
office, and also make such suggestions
and recommendations in regard
to trade with Indians as may be deemed
best for the interests of the service.

 In regard to the Agencies of New

Mexico, it is proper to state that, steps

Watkins 6
have recently been taken to remove the
Indians at Abiqnin and Cimarron:
the Apaches to Mescalero, and the Utes
to the Southern Ute Agency- and to 
discontinue those two Agencies. The Military will
aid in effecting the removal, and the Agents
have been notified to discontinue the
distribution of supplies to the Indians at those
two points, on, and after the 10th of April
next. It is reported to the office that many
of the Utes, are roaming at large over
some portions of New Mexico, that they
are disposed to engage in hostilities
against the settlers, and that they have
attempted to induce the Navajoes
to join them. You will report any
facts to the office that may be deemed
of importance in order that the evils
complained of, may be remedied.

Watkins 7  
Your attention is also called to the
importance of a thorough investigation
into the affairs of the Mescalero Agency,
serious complaints have been made 
against the Agent of that Agency, of
inefficiency, of having but little care over
the Indians under his charge, and
countenancing irregularities discreditable
to the service.

   Jicarrilla Apaches who have received

their supplies at Abiqnin and Cimarron
have, to some extent been averse to bring
placed upon the Mescalero reservation,
but it is believed with proper treatment
and efficient action on the
part of the Agent at Mescalero, they
may be induced to remain quietly
and contentedly with the Mescaleroes,
and give their attention to the cultivation

Watkins 8  
of the soil. A majority of these Indians
have expressed an earnest desire to be
placed upon a reservation, where they
can have land of their own to cultivate
and you will impress upon the Agent
the importance of encouraging them
by all the means and instrumentalities
in his power, in this laudable desire.

 It is important that measures be

taken to consolidate the Indians
of Arizona and New Mexico, upon
a less number of reservations, and
after you have made the necessary
investigations into the condition of the
agencies and their surroundings, you
will make such recommendation
in relation to the matter, and also
in regard to the desirable of removing
any of the tribes to the Indian Territory,

Watkins 9
its practicability & c. as the facts may
warrant.

  Other instructions may be given

you with regard to the service in
New Mexico and Arizona, if deemed
necessary, and you will be careful
to keep the office advised of your post
office address, or of the place where
communications may reach you.

                               Very respectfully
                                  Your obt. servt. 
                                      E A Hayt
                                      Commissioner

{Stevens}

Refer in reply to the following unclear               DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR,

                                                                               OFFICE OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
                                                                                  WASHINGTON,  March 23, 1878.

E. C. Watkins, Esq.

U. S. Indian Inspector,
 San Carlos agency, Arizona.

Sir:

        In the investigation of affairs at

agencies in Arizona and New Mexico, I desire that 
especial attention be given to the following 
subjects viz:

 Purchase of goods and supplies by the Agents

with or without authority from the Department.

 Character of the articles purchased, i.e.

their adaptability to the needs of the service;
the prices paid then for;
The delivery of supplies by contractors;

whether those furnished an equal to
contract requirements.

 The necessity for additional supplies

at San Carlos, for the remainder of the
current fiscal year,- what steps should be
taken to render the Indian producers.

  Much difficulty has been experienced

in the settlement of accounts on certified
vouchers for purchases made by agents. The
apparently exorbitant prices paid for goods
has caused great dissatisfaction and delay in
payments. In many cases large reductions
from the prices charged have been
made by the office before payment. This 
of course, is very embarrassing to the
office and has engendered a feeling of
distrust upon the park of merchants and
others who furnish supplies. In fact the
agent at the Pima agency has reported

Watkins 3.
that it is impossible for him to buy any
goods without cash in hand, and that it is
useless to advertise for supplies with the
view of making contracts, as he can get
no bids from anyone.

 Some dissatisfaction is experienced in

the matter of the beef and flour furnished by
the contractors at the San Carlos agency. I 
desire that you examine into this matter,
with the view of ascertaining what
additional measures are necessary to secure 
supplies of these articles equal to contract 
requirements, without having to resort to the
necessity of receiving goods of an inferior quality
at a reduction on the contract price.

 Additional supplies of beef, flour and corn

have been ordered from the contractors for the
San Carlos agency, to the extent of 25 per
centum over the quantities originally contracted

Watkins 4.
for. While it is apparent to this office that
these additional articles are needed, yet it
seems that some steps should be inaugurated
with the view of at least a portion of
the able-bodied Indians becoming producers,
instead of idle, listless consumers. Please
report upon this subject, giving the result of
your inquiries as to the proper course to be
pursued, and what is necessary to be done in
the premises.

  Agent Stout? reports that it is probable

that many of his Indians will suffer during
the coming season, in consequence of the long
continued absence of rain in his section of
country, and therefore has requested that
Congress be asked to make an appropriation of
$25,000- to relieve them in case his fears are
realized.

  Early reports upon the subjects

Watkins 5.
herein referred to, will aid the office in
correcting many abuses now existing.

  Please consult correspondence on these

subjects, on file in agency offices, for details
in regard to inferior supplies and high prices.

                               Very respectfully
                                       E A Hayt
                                     Commissioner

                                                                                               WASHINGTON, March 25th 1878

E.C Watkins Esq.
U.S Inspector
Camp Grant, A.F.
Sir:
Your attention is called to the proper disposition to be made of the 260 Warm Spring Indians, who broke away
from the San Carlos reservation last fall, who were subsequently arrested and are now held as prisoners at
Ojo Caliente, on the Southern Apache Agency, New Mexico.  Since the abandonment of that Agency the property
&c has been in charge of Dr. Walter Whitney, and he has also had a supervision

watkins 2
of these Indians since their arrival there.
Measures have been taken to dispose of the property, and it is necessary
that the office decide what is best to be done with the Indians.
On the 2nd ultimo, the attention of the Department was called to the matter, and in view
of the facts then before the office, it was suggested that the war department 
be requested to cause the necessary orders to be given to remove these prisoners to Fort Sill, Indian
Territory.  On reference of the subject by that Department to the General of the Army,
he discouraged such action on the ground that the Garrison at First Sill was not of sufficient
strength to maintain order among the prisoners, when the 260 Apaches were

Watkins 3
added to the number of Kiowas and other prisoners now at that point,
and on the further ground that the removal of these Indians would
necessarily be very expensive, as they "would have to be escorted nearly
1500 miles."  It is recommended by the Military Officer in charge of the prisoners,
that they be permitted to remain where they are, and that their families at
San Carlos have the privilege of joining them.  You will therefore at such time
as you may deem best, visit Ojo Caliente, and after a full investigation
of the condition of these Indians, once their surroundings, make such recommendation
as the facts warrant and as may be best for the interests of the service, keeping in mind the
great expense of maintaining them where they now are.

Warm Springs

DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR.  OFFICE OF INDIAN AFFAIRS  WASHINGTON, March 27th 1878
E.C Watkins Esq.
U.S Indian Inspector
Camp Grant, Arizona.
Sir:
You are advised that Indian traders have licenses to trade with Indians of the Pueblo Agency, in New Mexico, that expire,
as follows:  John W. Miller, March 29.1878; Auguste Lacoine, March 31. 1879; Eldodt Bro, March 20. 1879.  Santiago Baca, March 16.
1879, and Josephine Tondre, May 15. 1878.  and you are directed to inquire into the character and standing of each;
whether they are conducting their business, in every respect, in accordance

watkins 2
with the rules set forth in the Circular, a copy of which is transmitted
herewith, for your information; and report any and all irregularities you may find.
If you discover any person at the Pueblo Agency, who was formerly licensed and
is continuing trade with the Indians without a renewal thereof, you will cause the 
store of such person to be closed and their trade to cease.
Charles W. Lewis, is an applicant for a license to trade at the Pueblo Agency,
and an expression of your opinion as to the propriety of granting such
license, after you shall have obtained information upon which to base it, is desirable.
To trade with Indians of the Navajo

Watkins 3
Agency in New Mexico, there have been licensed:  Romulo Martinez, which expires
February 8, 1879; and Perry H. Williams, March 31, 1878, about whom you will make a like investigation
and report; also, pursue the same course in regard to persons continuing their trade, {if any are found}
after their licenses shall have expired.
You will also take congnizance of persons trading upon any of the Indian reservations, you may visit,
without licenses, by closing their stores and order them and their stock 
off the reservation, and in case of refusal, report such person to the nearest
U.S Attorney, that he may enforce the penalty of Section 2133.

Department of the Interior,

Agents will notify "agency traders" that in future when making purchases from, or sales
to, Indians, money only must be used.
The use of tokens, tickets, or store orders, will not be permitted.
They will also call upon the traders to furnish price lists of the principal articles
which they may have for sale; directing that they be made in such style as the
agents may indicate as best adapted to be understood by Indians as well a whites;
and that they be posted conspicuously in such places as may be selected by the agent, in
order that they may readily be consulted at any time.
A copy of such price list to be forwarded to this office.  Agents are further
instructed to notify this office of any cases in which Indians are charged higher prices than
whites, for similar goods.

By referring to vouchers 1.2.3 & 4 above referred to, it will be observed that said Expense was incurred
while En route from my home at Seattle.  W. J to assume charge of the Creek Bay Indian Agency.  I cannot
understand how a stronger or more Explicit Certificate can be made than is contained in Each of the aforesaid
vouchers, setting forth the necessities etc of the Expense!
Certainly the Indian Dept could not Expect me to pay my own travelling Expenses when
performing this necessary journey.  By referring to voucher No 5, it will be observed
that said voucher, contains a full and Explicit certificate of the necessities of the journey on which said
Expense was incurred.  Said journey was absolutely necessary for the interests of the service
as stated, and remark.  4 voucher 1.2.3.4 & 5 apply

"voucher 6 Schooner Winnifred, Transportation    27.50
The Agent must furnish his authority for incurring this Expense, Suspended"
Voucher 6.  with Bills of Lading etc, clearly sets forth the different articles shipped
for the use of the Agency by the Schooner Winnifred.  These articles, were purchased,
in open market for immediate use at the Agency.  Port Townsend the point at which they were purchased
and from whence shipped is 90 miles from Neuh Bay Agency and the only communication
is by water.  The amount charged by Schooner Winnifred was, 
not in excess of the usual rates, see certificate on voucher 6.
Said articles as before stated were purchased for immediate use at the Agency, which
I considered sufficient authority for their shipment.
Voucher 7  Rothschild, Supplies                                3204.36
The agent must furnish his authority for making this purchase.  Suspended"
The necessity for making this purchase must be my authority, for making the same.
The majority of these supplies were absolutely needed for
immediate use at the Indian School and had they note been provided it
would of necessity have been discontinued
Several communities had been addressed to the Hon Commissioners setting
forth these necessities and asking instructions thereto, to none of which I had 
received a reply, I fully believed that the exigencies of the case fully warranted
me in making the purchase and that the Indian regulations provided for such
purchases under similar circumstances in open market.  It will be observed
that voucher 7 contains a full and explicit certificate in regard to said purchase
and I would respectfully ask the Hon Commissioner take into consideration the
peculiar circumstances of the case.
"Voucher 8 Wm Gallick'    Supplies                     113.52
The agent must furnish his authority for making this purchase, also state the number
of pounds in each box of bread, crackers and soap, and in the future take up all
goods so many pounds or so many in numbers Suspended"
In regard to the authority for the purchase 
the foregoing remarks to voucher 7 apply.
The original bills of purchase of the hard bread and soap did not give
the number of pounds and they were so expended on my property return.
A/n will observe however by enclosed certificate of Expenditure of supplies
for that quarter by the Matron and of myself, the total number of pounds
both of hard bread and soap are given.

" Voucher 9 O.A Huntington          Letter press.                      12.00
Remarks to Voucher 9. apply.
On assuming charge of the Agency I found this letter press in use in the office
and claimed by O.A Huntington the ex agent as his private property.
All correspondence etc, of the Agency had been kept in letter press book, two of
which books were afterwards returned by the Hon Commissioner at Washington to the
Creek Bay Agency, and I considered it highly essential that this letter press be
returned at the Agency inasmuch had it not have been purchased by the
Government, Mr. Huntington would have removed it as his private property.
"Voucher 10    Geo W Hill.       Travelling Ex.                              5.00
Remarks to Voucher 1 apply."
This expense as in Vouchers 1,2,3,4 & 5. was incurred while travelling on business
strictly pertaining to the Dept. and the interests of the service as set forth in
certificate attached to all of said vouchers.
All of these journeys were performed in the most Expeditious manner possible by
the shortest routes and at the lowest rates, as for instance the trip from
Port Townsend to Victoria was for the purpose of taking a transient tug
at the latter place, for Neah Bay, there being no regular communication from
Port Townsend to Neah Bay other than once a week and that is by a

small sail vessel.  Entirely unreliable.
It will be observed that many of these journeys were performed without expense
to the government, as for instance the journey from Victoria to Neah Bay also
from Neah Bay to Port Townsend in two or three instances, no fare being charged.
I certify on honor that all travelling Expenses represented in the before named
vouchers were incurred precisely as represented in the certificates attached
thereto, and the said journeys as performed were absolutely necessary for the interests
of the service.

E. C Watkins, Esq.                                                                           June 27, 1878
U.S Indian Inspector
Santa Fe.
New Mexico
Sir: 

               Agent Pyle of the Navajo Agency New Mexico, on the 30" mistauk made

request that the ambulances belonging to the Southern Apache Agency, be transferred to
his Agency.
Referring to instructions in my letter to you of 4 April last relative to property of the
above mentioned Agency, for which Agent James Davis is responsible, I have
to say that, Agent Pyle has been directed

to confer with you in regard to the matter, and if the ambulance has not already
been sold, and can be transported to his Agency at a small cost you are
instructed to transfer it to him, taking his receipt for the same, which should
be filed with Agent Davis' papers, as his mucher for the disposition made
of the property.
Respectfully 
E A Hayes
Comissioner

Copy.

State of Colorado
County of Ouray      S.S

Personally appeased before me, Clerk and Recorder in and for the county and 
state aforesaid, John B, Outealt, who being duly sworn according to law, deposes as follows:
That during the last three years, up to the latter part of June, 1878, he has been in
the service of the Government, as Carpenter, at the Lost Pino's Indian Agency, Colorado;
That while in said service he became cognizant of certain irregularities practiced
by the present Agent in charge, Joseph B. Abbott, which in the opinion of this deponent
are of sufficient importance to lay before the Department for such action in the premises
as it may deem just and proper -
The deponent says that the said Agent in accounting for issues to Indians and other
expenditures, adopts the very convenient method of taking the names of
employees as witnesses to such expenditure on blank vouchers, filling in the quantities
after the signatures have been obtained,
The Interpreter, Jesus Marino, being unable to read English.
Fearing to lose his place in case of refusal, the Deponent at first reluctantly
consented in several cases to sign his

name to these blanks as a witness, but ultimately, in the month of March, 1878, refused
to comply unless filled up with the quantities actually issued.
From that time he, the department, has never again been called upon to sign anything,
and in the following month of June was discharged from the service by the said Agent.
The deponent further states that the said Abbott when leaving the East to enter
upon the duties of his office as Indian Agent, was accompanied, as he is informed, by a
person named William Flint, ant that the travelling expenses of said person, by stage
from Indian Creek to said Agency, a distance of about seventy-five miles, were by private
understanding with the stage contractors, covered up as the Agent's individual expenses,
thus charging the Government with a larger amount than would otherwise have been the case.
The deponent further states that said Flint is carried on the polls of employees as
Chief Herder, and drawing pay as such, although he has never, since his
arrival at the Agency, in the month of January, 1878, done any service in that
capacity, but is looked upon as a privileged

to dispose of; that Mr. Holt the Agency miller, superintends the kitchen arrangements,
assisted by his wife and a hired girl, all of whom as subsisted at the Agency, at the
expense of the Government and the Indians, and further the deponent saith not.
Signed     John B. Outcalt
Subscribed and sworn to before me
this 19th day of July A.D. 1878,
Signed, Alfred E, Long
County Clerk.
Ouray Co. Colo
